Ghost Recon Wildlands isn't just a game; it's an epic adventure waiting to be experienced. From the moment you step foot into the sprawling landscapes of Bolivia, you're immersed in a world teeming with danger, intrigue, and endless possibilities. Developed by Ubisoft Paris and released in 2017, this masterpiece of a game sets a new standard for open-world tactical shooters.

First and foremost, the sheer size and detail of the world in Ghost Recon Wildlands are breathtaking. Bolivia comes alive with vibrant ecosystems, from dense jungles to towering mountains, each area offering its own unique challenges and opportunities. The attention to detail is astonishing, with every tree, rock, and building meticulously crafted to create an immersive and believable environment.

But it's not just about the world; it's about what you can do in it. Ghost Recon Wildlands gives you unparalleled freedom to tackle missions however you see fit. Want to approach stealthily, using silenced weapons and careful coordination to take down enemies without alerting reinforcements? You can do that. Prefer to go in guns blazing, unleashing chaos and destruction at every turn? Go ahead. The choice is yours, and the game rewards creativity and adaptability at every turn.

One of the standout features of Ghost Recon Wildlands is its seamless integration of co-op multiplayer. Teaming up with friends to tackle missions together is an absolute blast, with each player bringing their own unique skills and playstyles to the table. Whether you're coordinating synchronized sniper shots or causing mayhem with explosives, the cooperative experience is second to none and adds a whole new layer of enjoyment to the game.

And let's not forget about the story. While some open-world games sacrifice narrative depth for the sake of freedom, Ghost Recon Wildlands strikes a perfect balance. The tale of the Ghosts' mission to dismantle the Santa Blanca cartel is gripping and immersive, with memorable characters, intense cutscenes, and plenty of twists and turns to keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.

In conclusion, Ghost Recon Wildlands is nothing short of a masterpiece. With its stunning open-world design, deep and rewarding gameplay mechanics, and unforgettable cooperative multiplayer experience, it sets a new standard for what an open-world tactical shooter can and should be. Whether you're a fan of the genre or just looking for an epic adventure to lose yourself in, Ghost Recon Wildlands delivers in spades.

Combat is okay. Once alerted enemies always know your exact location and can shoot you through cover with near perfect accuracy. Ridiculous that coked out gangsters have better accuracy than your supposed elite operators. Once actual combat starts your AI companions are effectively worthless. The game is really balanced around having four players so solo play can be frustrating. 

The forced stealth sections of the game are infuriating. You can spend 15 minutes slowly creeping through a mission only to be forced to start over due to one mistake or just bad luck. Enemies can see you at huge distances any time they're facing you and can often see through solid cover. The lack of ability to move bodies so they aren't discovered turns these sections into a tedious waiting game for the enemies to slowly patrol out of the paths you need to cross.

Driving feels pretty good with many of the vehicles handling better than they probably should. Most vehicles are fun to drive with the exception of the armored SUV and APC. This is good because you're going to be spending a lot of time traveling to each objective. Once you do a few rebel operations you can unlock the ability to spawn a helicopter every minute or so which will greatly speed up your ability to go from objective to objective. The exception being some provinces which are so covered in SAM sites that any air travel is nearly impossible.

Progression wise if you seek out all the available skill point bonuses you'll usually be limited more by scavenged resources for upgrading skills. The random small caches are basically pointless after the early game and you'll primarily be hitting convoys to get the resources you need. These are a hassle until you upgrade the EMP drone that lets you easily stop a convoy and pick off the guards easily.

Overall, there's some fun to be had between long tedious sections and others that are infuriatingly unbalanced. A flawed buy playable game.

This is a review that I should have written 7 years ago, when I was completely lost in fictitious Bolivia! (Yes, Bolivia is a real country but the locations in this game are not.) 

This game is one of the most fun I've had with my friends in a long time. 
I never really got into any of the Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon games before Wildlands, so I was compeletely new to the special forces and their covert missions.
From the first trailer I was hooked. What an interesting villain (El SueÃ±o) with a whole cartel of characters that are still memorable over 5 years later. 

Never before and never since have I enjoyed picking up a multitude of vehicles to drive or fly around to my missions. What other game lets you ride a tractor to battle? (except farming simulators...) 

The movement is smooth (vaulting over things, running, etc.) and satisfying. 

The map is divided into different sections that are controlled by parts of the cartel, that need to be taken down. Even though each part of the map has recurring missions that might sound tedious or repetitive, I never felt like I was simply grinding the missions to advance. I loved collecting things, helping people, killing bad guys (and girls) and sneak around. 

The whole world in Wildlands is beautiful, there's people and animals that you can interact with. Yes, if you leave your vehicle on the street a whole traffic jam will occur. You have an impact, you are a person in their world not just a player in a map. 
On top of all the regular missions there's secrets you learn by talking to NPCs. I still remember the town that is completely inhabited by only dogs or the legend of El Tio.

There's also a whole thing about weapons and customizations but I'm going to be honest, I did not care about weapons when playing. As long as I could kill the enemies, I did not care whether my gun was more or less accurate. To learn more about this, another review might be more helpful. 

I've already played 180 hours and I have not yet seen the end of the game. I can wholeheartedly recommend this game. You should play it with your friends and free Bolivia!

Good game if you have friends.

Ofc you can solo, but it's more fun to be tactical and call shots during missions with friends.

Graphics is amazing, very immersive especially during rainy days and the volumetric fog at night makes you feel like you are looking at the real thing.

Cons would be the enemies sometimes spawn on top of you and they have pin point accuracy and never miss.

The "Tier system" at lvl 30 is also a joke. It's basically their way of time gating you so you keep playing the game to unlock more stuff (which you should already be doing while doing missions anyways).

All in all, a solid 4.5\5 and would definitely recommend to anyone.

I've played Breakpoint for 300+ hours across 3 platforms PS, Xbox, and now PC with mods and vanilla. I have to install 50 mods just to truly get the true Ghost Recon experience and make is realistic as possible and let me tell you it's one of the worst games to mod. That being said if this wasn't Steam and we weren't on PC I don't think I could recommend this game, however we are on PC, so we're not locked at 30 FPS and can push the graphics to insane levels. I first played this game on PS4, but never really got that far and ended up playing Breakpoint instead, big mistake. The more I play this game the more I hate modern Ubi and Breakpoint. I like many of you I have the treacherous backlog curse where I buy games in bulk that are on sale that I just never played while also buying new games, but this game is worthy of your time. Hell I'm about to get FarCry 5 on sale and get Dragon's Dogma 2 on release lol. Long story short if you're on M&K I don't see the old movement and gameplay being too much of an issue however it is the one thing about this game that hasn't aged well. All in all if it's not a problem this is one of the best Ghost Recon games ever made! Don't buy Breakpoint get Wildlands it's good for your health. P.S. I paid full price it's that good.

If you've ever asked yourself "What is a Ubisoft game?", then you obviously haven't played this.
The movement feels far too robotic, and reminiscent of the division 1's system; the gameplay loop feels like it's from far cry 3, with a biiiiiiiig map and a biiiiiiig list of TO-DOs; and the game feels like it's 80% developed, with godawful flight controls and literal GTA AI. I've heard some good reviews of this game, fine, it might just be me. But, if I'm buying a game with a different name and a different genre to all the other "tom clancy" games, I expect something different.
If you liked the modern far cry games, go for it: it's basically a milsim TPS DLC. Otherwise, save your money, for the love of all things good in this world.

Wildlands was my favorite shooter of 2017, and no game since has quite hit the same niche of large-scale, 3rd-person, semi-stealth combat with a focus on gunplay and spotting. It encourages planned and carefully executed assaults in a way that most modern shooters fail to. You wanna pretend you're special forces without dealing with the intricacy of milsim shooters? This is the ticket. Also, Breakpoint sucks, so buy this instead on a sale.

The map is sprawling. It's chock-full of content that you can easily play for 100 hours without getting bored. Inserting in a heli, rucking over a hill to a sniper spot, and picking off sentries before moving in to loot a base is satisfying every time. The enemy AI become weirdly omniscient once you get detected, but your AI allies are wallhacking aimbots, so it all balances out. The game also has some things to say about American military and economic intervention in South America... but it doesn't commit to its messages very well. The story and dialogue are better than your average modern military shooter, but this is no "Spec Ops: The Line."

Just watch out--weapon stat cards lie, and Ubisoft's store and UPlay integration are terrible. Those can be ignored easily enough.

ghost recon wildlands is certainly not the most amazing game out there and not even what the trailers promissed if you ask me.
but still: busting through fictional bolivia and doing the ubisoft busywork kinda is very fun in this one. maybe not very innovative, mind you, but fun. 
the tom clancy logo should be ignored - although by now noone really thinks that has any meaning anymore, right?
the graphics are stellar (and fairly well optimised) and the sound-design is great as well. since it's a vast open world, assets will repeat themselves a lot, but with the visuals they managed to mix it up enough for it to not be too obvious. sadly the same can't be said about the voice-acting: the overly "cool" and "badass" lines your character and your companions tend to spout will be rather annoying at some point... 
the AI is... ok i guess, but you will wish for coop-players because while it does the job, the order-wheel with which you command your AI comrades is rather limited and it is just easier and more fun to come up with neat little tactics to engage the enemy when you do it with your friends. the enemies are not stupid but not the cleverest either and in the beginning of the game rather "blind". but things will increase in difficulty the more often you run into heavily armed unidad or cartell squads. the unidad is relentless in their pursuit and you may wish for them to be "blind" soon enough.
as mentioned before: the world is filled with the usual open world collectables, side missions, and so forth. it's quite enjoyable to tag medical supplies and ammo etc, and gladly the map is visually and thematically varied enough to keep you playing if you enjoy exploring. if you don't care about exploration, the missions will have you see a lot of the map quickly enough. 
missions will be the same old, same old at some point but they tried mixing it up. with this amount of stuff to do only CD project red managed to keep it interessting. but they worked on it for longer and actually did care ;)

gladly the microtransactions and general monetisation is not the worst out there, but the whole pricing for a gold or deluxe edition is crap. buy the standard edition on sale and you will have your moneys worth.

in short: wildlands is in a weird spot right in the middle of ArmA and GTA online :D
you have light tactical elements and a variety if guns and tools to take it seriously and try playing cleverly... but on the other hand you can go in guns blazing with an armored SUV or genereally just dick around and have fun your way.

I actually started playing Ghost Recon Breakpoint first which IS setup to allow single players a reasonable shot at achieving everything. So I tried Wildlands but in single player mode which I prefer - it just doesn't really deliver. Too much pain, too little gain.

This is a bit of an interesting one. 

The open world of this game is huge, explorable but memorable. I personally really like how much work got put into this game, it's really well made. 
Storywise [spoiler] the game starts up pretty nice, the missions are really well designed and it genuinely is fun to play. But you'll probably still be disappointed with the ending.  [/spoiler]
The graphics and performance are a bit ehh, but what do you expect from a game developed by Ubisoft? They are still alright and you get to know the graphics settings very easily. Resolution scaling tends to set itself to x2, which is really annoying because you get no profits from it except lower framerates if that's a profit in your eyes. 

The Multiplayer gets it's own little part, because it's an outstanding multiplayer storygame in my opinion and I'm really surprised that I say that for a game developed by Ubisoft. Heads up, good job people. But even if you don't have friends to play with, in this game you get help from bots that you can communicate with and command, which can be really satisfying. 

The skilltree is a bit overpowered in my opinion. I purposefully didn't buy some things, because it would make the game too easy and boring, so be careful with upgrading the skilltree, if you want to keep the difficulty. And the last thing that annoys me a bit are the loaing times, because they can take disgustingly long, even though I have an NVME SSD built in. Joining servers can also take a long time. 

In general a very great game, can recommend 10/10

This game is one of few that have, and will continue to capture a sense of nostalgia. We will all look back on Ghost Recon Wildlands the way our parents look back at Pong, Jump Man and Pac Man. 
Why do I feel so strongly this way? Because GRW did something that no other game has captured in such a way during it's life. It was one of the last good games made by a triple A company that was actually decent. You have full control of the outcome of every fight; your methods, tactics, approach angle, detection, CQB or long range, on foot or in a vehicle. Not to mention the customization and ability to play with friends.
Was it perfect? No, absolutely not, fuck DLC and micro-transactions. But it was unique. Goodbye GRW. I hope we see another of our favorites re-imagined in such a beautiful way before triple A titles are all $70 base price with $100 in DLC to make it playable, thus forcing us to play only indie games. This game is incredibly pretty, and I don't just mean the visuals which are also top notch but almost everything about it is really commendable if you are a fan of open world games that are shooters in nature, but slightly harder in some aspects than your average 3rd person open world ordeal that's lacking a sort of coherent and complex narrative. 

I found the game to be highly immersive and good, if not great except perhaps the clunky gameplay which I tend to think is because it's somewhat of an old game coming from 2017 because also games have become a lot smoother since then both in their graphical streaming and gameplay. Of course high graphical fidelity games that run super smooth have existed in the past but just not necessarily in such an extent as - for at least at the time of release of this game - their scope, and I believe that is one of the aspects where its clunkiness comes from, that it's an (Ubisoft) original. By that I don't mean a jab at, but rather to say: it's an original game for its size. Not many other games come to mind that are as big and wide as this one is but a few do come to mind and they usually come from Ubisoft as well.

A few games in recent times that I have played from that era were also kind of clunky in their execution while others certainly were not and beauty of games goes for me a long way back so the pure beauty of Wildlands isn't necessarily in what it shows and how it shows it; it's a "techno-thriller" action/adventure game / tactical experience with very true to life game mechanics like the one shot one kill / death mechanic which really goes back to original Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six games which at the time of their release were truly original games with original mechanics and so: ideas behind them; where most of the other games were sort of blends of Fantasy themes and not really ever high-detail mili-tech, and such games are not really replicated a lot in a slew of games since that time. That is one aspect I appreciate about Wildlands, one that I embrace and one that I miss often in others, despite that this sort of theme feels like a niche.

Its quote/unquote -realism- which can be found in many aspects beyond the damage model is what appeals to me really and honestly appeals to me most out of many other game related themes. World or the geography of the game's world would be another example as would be: the story as well. I find that a lot of these aspects are actually bound to this Tom Clancy methodology which also go back to the writer's books as a core foundation establishing a legacy of someone who sold insurance for a living and had nothing to do with neither books nor games but who would later expand into both and have I would say pretty big success with. This game extends and in some regards expands on that legacy.

Realism of Wildlands appears in many factors which makes the game unique in even Ubisoft's catalogue of Tom Clancy's games but I feel are not necessarily alien to the person themself.

Realism also comes back in a few more aspects than gameplay alone as I eluded to before in context of damage mechanics and gameplay in terms of dealing that damage and receiving it and this cat and mouse or predator and prey type of gameplay becomes really the core aspect of the game which to some like myself would be enough to enjoy a gaming experience but Wildlands does much more with that core, aspect of the core loop of the gameplay because it makes the whole experience interconnected together because it blends together with many immersive and personal experiences like: exploration, discovery, understanding, expectation, learning and trial and error of amongst whom the lore it exposes and realism it allows you to experience in an immersive and sometimes very hectic and exciting way stand out to a high degree. Pleasure and enjoyment included!

Things like vehicles, tools and gadgets and weapons enhance this immersion which I think for the developers might have been a bit of a gamble because next to the story's exposition Wildlands is very limited in the way it is scripted and all the action that happens in the game involving the player, the player themselves initiates which is also another aspect of realism that makes the game, compared to other games stand out in essence in a sort of elegant way due to the simplicity these elements that game's realism provide. No explosion will happen unless player choses it to happen. It's like, making a choice. If it's a good choice it will work and if the player has made a bad choice then they start over, which admittedly is not realistic as in the real world so much as it is in a gaming context where the sandbox is the playground and you play it your way, given the circumstance and given the tools and the means, you chose your way, and usually in a split second  i.e. you make the choices and the choices revolve around you who is responsible to evolve the game furtherâ¦ This seems simple and logical until you realize that you've spent playing the game for years nowâ¦

Something to savor?

Clunkiness of the game, makes the game harder than it has to be but also in a sense it makes you rely more on aspects found within it, like one thing that stands out is for instance the power of teammates and rebels who you deploy as in a sort of Guerilla warfare type of way against seemingly an overwhelming enemy but the enemy in the game isn't so much overwhelming as that they are precise. They usually come in small groups and it's an even playfield in terms of damage taking and dealing and in this sense the game makes you as the player attempt a different type of approach that you would, playing other games that involve bulletsponges and more fantastic elements for in here are no healing items (there is life regeneration albeit slow) and there are no power-ups. There is only skill that comes in and persists through experience and knowledge, not necessarily overpoweredness like just a sheer numbers advantage or reliance on heavy metal of various shapes forms and sizes like superior body armor, brute force of war machines like tanks or the brunt of a thousand missiles raining down through artillery and patience of a siege for this skill gathered through what seems to be years of experience comes through knowledge and understanding of your weaknesses and strong points which this game has an interesting way of implementing and leaving it up to you to figure out what to do with and how.

â¦

So by referring to "game's clunkiness" I might as well had been referring to my own self because there were countless instances of situations that kept repeating where I would die simply because the aimbot like aim of the opponents and my inability despite having high frames in game of not being able to react in time to have a fair fighting chance where the enemy would simply pawn me and rinse and repeat until I became better. Clunkiness of the game can appear through the fact that the game auto switches between third and first person while aiming, that this leaves you somewhat disoriented and not being able to aim well at the enemy after you auto-lean out of cover to shoot, and the fact that when aiming down the sights the FOV zooms in so reaction times as well as overall vision of what is in front of you become hindered, and truly because of this the importance of correct positioning and angles of view from out of cover that you have to make in order not to die a lot and through maneuvering from place to place in game and so effectively learning to play the game become more apparent. I have managed to become better at it so about towards the end but still I think that if the game had more refined gameplay like for instance is found in Breakpoint, it would have saved me a lot of if noting loading of previous saves because the difficulty is really up there.

On the highest difficulty it's a darn hard game though so better pucker your buttholes, meaning: learn to become patient and learn to play

Ghost Recon Wildlands is an exceptional open-world game that offers an engaging and immersive experience, particularly in co-op and solo gameplay. Ubisoft has truly showcased the talent of its environment and asset designers, creating a vast and dynamic world that is breathtaking in its detail and diversity. From the lush jungles and towering mountains to the bustling cities and dusty rural settlements, every corner of Ghost Recon Wildlands is a pleasure to explore.

The game's weather and day-night cycle effects add another layer of realism and immersion, with rainstorms, fog, and varying light conditions that affect visibility and gameplay. The sound design is equally impressive, with realistic gunfire, ambient noise, and a stirring soundtrack that heightens the tension and excitement of each mission.

In terms of game design, Ghost Recon Wildlands is a high-quality experience that offers a compelling blend of stealth, shooter, and open-world gameplay. While some may find the gameplay to be repetitive at times, the advanced AI ensures that each encounter is challenging and engaging. Enemy soldiers react intelligently to the player's movements and actions, taking cover, calling for backup, and using tactical maneuvers to flush out the player. This level of detail and challenge makes each mission feel rewarding and satisfying.

The game's story is another highlight, offering a gritty and realistic portrayal of a drug cartel's stranglehold on a fictionalized Bolivia. The player takes on the role of a Ghost, an elite special forces operative tasked with dismantling the cartel's operations and bringing its leaders to justice. The story is well-written and well-acted, with a cast of memorable characters and a strong sense of moral ambiguity.

Overall, Ghost Recon Wildlands is a must-play for fans of stealth, shooter, or open-world games. Its stunning setting, engaging gameplay, and compelling story make it a standout title in the genre, and one that is well worth experiencing for yourself.

We all know Ubisoft, they always pick quantity over quality. But even them, once in a while produce simply a good dame. That was the case with Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands. It is still a sandbox full of repetitive side quests but it is not all that terrible. There are few crazy missions that can test your patience but it is all doable, even on harder difficulties.

The graphics are still good to look at, especially at higher resolutions. The only things that feel dated are character models. Performance wise I had no issues, although I had one graphic glitch where I fell through the floor and opened parachute below the map. Sounds and dialogues are good, story is decent. Music/radio is not my cup of tea so I was playing my own tracks in the background. Gameplay is surprisingly smooth and easy to learn.

Back in 2017 when I first played Ghost Recon Wildlands it had a pretty solid multiplayer, but unfortunately it is pretty much dead now. Still if you don't mind playing this solo or have few friends to play 4 man coop, you should have a blast for most of the time. 

Today when I was finishing the game to 100% I felt kinda sad, in a good way, as I will slightly miss the diverse biomes that this open world had to offer. It was simply fun to roam around through forests, dirt roads in the mountains etc. Although you will realise that apart from clone missions and occasional secrets there isn't much in this virtual Bolivia, you can still add some extra immersion of your own - for example by customising your AI companions look depending on the climate of the zone you are clearing. For me it was fun to change weapons and clothing in each new area.
If you still have not tried this game out you should, better now before it gets too old to be enjoyable. Myself, I will consider playing this once again in couple of years.

PS: Ubisoft launcher is annoying as it doesn't remember your credentials, so you need to pop them each time you want to play the game. But it is at least quick as the launcher itself is not bugged. Yup, still Ubisoft as we know it.

Also, do NOT but any DLC for this game. They just suck (tried them in 2017 on PS4).

Upon initial glance I thought the game was going to be another bland open world shooter. After playing it for a few hours I can start to understand the appeal, and go to know certain mechanics in this game that work a lot better than other shooters. In short, this game is good (and even better with friends), but does have a few limitations that may put off potential players.

Ghost Recon Wildlands' (GRW) [b]gameplay[/b] is a lot more engaging that I initially assumed. In my opinion, the gun handling/shooting in this game far exceeds a lot of other shooters (and dare I say, Call of Duty). It's satisfying, it feels real, the impact feels proper, and bullet delivery (especially with snipers) feels like it was done right. Although this is the highlight of the game for me, there are other features that players may buy into. The open world concept is a little overwhelming at first. As the player does a few missions and begins to notice how the game is structured, completing missions and acquiring new abilities becomes a little easier. The user interface and menus try their best to break down what the player can or should do next. At first the game's missions may seem a little "easy" compared to the initial Ghost Recon I played back on the Xbox. As the game progresses, some of the missions begin to get difficult objectives which challenge the player. If you are playing this game yourself the AI soldiers actually provide a decent amount of support. Though, I don't understand how sometimes friendly soldiers can move in front of the enemy, even if it is behind a buildings shadow midday. There are a few vehicles to choose from in the game from cars, trucks, mounted trucks, helicopters, and planes.

The [b]visuals and graphics[/b] are pretty good for a game of its era. Although the landscape looks stunning (and shaders seem to be really well done to reflect its beauty) the minor animations seem to be there. NPCs are interacting with one another (to some degree), enemies are patrolling and sometimes engage with their environment. Even though this is a large map game it can make the player feel like they're right there in the village, simply looking around and exploring (or sneaking and hiding). The [b]sounds and music[/b] are satisfactory. The radio is a little in what in can play, but Spanish music can be heard blaring while rolling on four wheels. There is interaction between the soldiers (and sometimes NPCs). The voice acting itself is suitable to a triple A game (especially coming from an Early Access game). Both domains were done well (especially the visuals), but I feel the sounds department could've done a little more to immerse the player.

Overall, this is a pretty good game given certain circumstances. Playing solo can be fun for about ten hours before some missions can seem extremely difficult without the support of another player, and sometimes boring without friends to play with. I'm happy I purchased it on sale - and would recommend the same to the reader! The driving is a little wonky/blocky and other little small movements throughout the game share the same value.

Completed this in 106 hours of casual and highly enjoyable game play.  This is a true Open World game -- if you wanted to you could walk one side of the enormous map to the other without any unrealistic barriers.  You'll find that cliffs will block your path now and then, but just walk around or fly over them.

The story-line is great and very detailed with many many tidbits of lore and background history scattered around to pick up.  I played this on the easiest difficulty and it was still a decent challenge - especially the incredible final mission against the main bad guy.

It is easy to play this whole game without the online features and without purchasing any extra guns from the store for real money.  The in-game guns are quite good and there are many to be found around the map.

This game is absolutely HUGE in terms of map area.  And it's a beautiful game even on low graphics settings.  If you have a powerful PC then you're in for a treat.

Despite the plot, this story portrays Bolivia and its history in a positive light, for the most part.

It gets pretty dark in places though, so if you're of a weak disposition, be ready for some grim themes.

This is a great open-world game, and a key title in the series.  I would say it has to be one of the best values for your money in my library.  My friends and I have sunk over 160 into the campaign, and we weren't really wasting any time.  The game rewards patience and tactical teamwork.  The story line is a bit over the top, but not entirely unbelievable.  The Graphics are great, even this many years after release.  They do a great job of building a world you can get lost in.  There's incredible attention to detail, and no end of things to do.  Late game became a bit much to handle, and we never actually completed it.  The enemy tends to be somewhat unaware of the benefit of cover, and seem like bullet sponges at times.  But if you have a small group of buddies who want to take down the cartel, you're gonna love this!

Wonderful game. I keep going back to the singleplayer campaign. Takes some time to figure out the result of completing missions and how to progress the storyline, but once you're into it you're on an exciting journey through a beautifully realised Bolivia. Lots of little touches to show the culture and the country, while being in massive firefights. Once you get good at fighting your instincts/muscle memory will become amazing and give you all the adrenaline and reward you could want from a game like this. I always thought this would be a game I would like, but I held off purchasing because others said it wasn't so good, but they were wrong and it was even better than I could have imagined. Played it to death and uninstalled (through entire campaign two and a bit times, and played the expansions), but reinstalled just to be back in Bolivia doing stuff. It's still a much better game than Breakpoint, which I've tried and tried to love. Wildlands is my Ghost Recon home.

I am a 56 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my daughter, who is 13 now. My daughter got this game for Christmas in 2023 from her uncle, so we installed it on her computer and she started playing. By the end of the week she had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my daughter, as she is always out with her friends or just watching overweight men eating large amounts of food and crying on YouTube. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my daughter since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my daughter closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. There isn't much to say about this game except it's incredible. If you have a high end device capable of running this game on ultra, it is incredibly detailed for a game of its time. The story is amazing, combat is amazing, completing objectives completely undetected whilst taking out cartel members from hundreds of metres away(amazing). The gun mechanics are incredible, for a Tom Clancy's game it is much closer to realistic in terms of bullet spray/drop, recoil. I haven't had more fun in any game involving stealth and espionage. The amazing range of clothing, and weaponry along with an amazing selection of paint presets from a military POV(as in there aren't any bright colours except for some specific clothing items). Other than vehicle spawning being a bit funky sometimes(mainly with planes), there isn't anything bad I have to say about this game. My experiences have always been unique and engaging and there isn't one way you can go about a mission. Even if you are required to complete a mission completely undetected, you can choose to sneak in past enemies, or sneak in whilst strategically assassinating cartel members like you do it for a living. If you need something to do in your spare time, I highly recommend purchasing this game. If anything i described sounds like a game you would like, I can assure you, you will absolutely love it.

Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildland's is the most interesting application of the Ubisoft formula to date. 

The plot surrounds a team of special operatives that go by the name Ghosts who can either be your AI companions or co-op friends. The Ghost's objective is to take down El Sueno and his cartel. 

The gameplay revolves around going to different provinces in real life Bolivia to liberate them with the help of the Rebels in the area who are fighting against the Cartel State alongside you. 

There are brilliantly crafted, fully animated cut-scenes that are fully optional (but totally worth it) and the game leaves a lot of freedom of how easy or hard, and immersive or arcade-y the player wants it to be. Settings such as removing crosshairs, more realistic AI, limited HUD, etc. can allow for the player to decide if they want something more akin to traditional Ubisoft shooters, or opt for a more realistic, tactical experience. 

The progression in the game is very satisfying and doing side content is incentivized with cosmetics, guns, attachments, and rebel assistance through drops and back up; all are fun and get rewarding content, but almost none are necessary to completing the game. 

I spent ~67 hours in game at the time of writing this review but I immediately moved on to the sequel after this, and will probably come back to Wildlands at some point, I can easily see myself putting 200+ hours into this game before I'm done with it.

Can't use mortar emplacements. Mini gun on chopter weak against vehicles. Did I mention ammo is everywhere.

 In the end I really wish I could jump between all of my teammates in order to set up some cool raids like in the Original Ghost Recon. Also miss the character building of my crew, leveling them all up, having to choose who to give the points to at the end of a mission and whether or not to restart the grueling mission or continue on, if, god forbid, one of my longtime characters had perished. 

 Great graphics and world but hollow gameplay elements eventually lead me to my decision that you should only buy this game if it's on sale. What a shame as Wildlands was an obviously large undertaking and Ubisoft decided to release this almost complete product that could've been a remarkable feather in their already full cap.

This is one of the games where I'm really split. In the beginning i found it far too easy. It is more fun on the extreme setting and later in tier-mode.
+ One-shot kills
+ sensible weapon customization mechanics
+ missing "numbers game" (i.e. you need to wear down the enemey with ridiculous amounts of hits... (even pistol one-shot kills are possible on head-shots).
- loot-boxes (mostly for cosmetic stuff, but also for additional weapons and vehicles, esp. the vehicles change abilities in game, as you can not call in an armed helicopter as transport vehicle until you find it in a loot box)
- (esp in tier mode) unrealistic enemy behaviour. e.g. snipers see you within seconds when you enter their viewcone and cross the imaginary view area boundary, sometimes also outside of their viewcone (i.e. when stealth approaching from behind)
- impossible spawning behaviour (i.e. clearing and barring and area with mines after, but enemies spawn between the barrier and you after moving forward; enemies spawning in impossible locations that have been cleard and are basically dead-ends. This is esp. irksome as the game in it's setup (and the original Tom Clancys brand legacy (yes, which has been dilluted by the more recent entries since the UbiSoft era, i know) would be the perfect open world stealth game without this problem, take your time stealth clearing an area and carefully approaching an objective, taking out enemies that go clear of their buddies , only to be killed by reinforcments spawned in between your AI buddies or something.
- (esp in tier mode) sometimes impossibly fast detection by enemies (e.g. running around a corner, but immediately seing you hunkered down behind cover, only very partially visible or behind shrubberies, insta kill while the enemy is running.
- As soon as one enemy spots you, ALL enemies know where you are, even if you kill that enemy half a second later and he never would have had a chance to tell anyone (yes, I'm looking at you, stealth missions, short burst to the head of enemy 1, short burst to the head of enemy 2, but enemy 3 spots you a splitsecond before burst to his head. Yeah, you are done, mission restart.)
- there are some stealth missions, where you have a timer running, but are not allowed to kill enemies initially.  The randomly spawned enemies make this unnecessarily hard.

+/- don't play alone, best played with four additional actual human players (that you know, don't play public games). In Solo play your AI can revive you once (2 or 3 times with upgrade). In MP you can infitnitely heal and the mission is not completely restarted when someone dies, they get respawned somewhat close and have to reapproach. Which esp on longer missions with an attempted stealth approach is terribly annoying.

So yeah, It was some fun, but it also was very annoying (esp when playing solo).

[b] Overview [/b]

One of my favourite games, 9.5/10. Play through the game at your own pace, some of the best fun is learning to build effective and fun gear sets, and learning how to explore and traverse the map is another great part of learning the game. However, there is one thing you should do after learning how the game works and what play-style you enjoyâ¦ [b] Complete Remanzo EARLY[/b], as sometimes an objective won't spawn, soft-locking the story, and requiring restarting with a new save until it spawns. There can be some jank, but it's usually not an issue, and some reviews really oversell how glitchy the game can be. Ubisoft and U-play sucks. Easy Anti-Cheat can suck, make sure it's not being registered as malware by your security program of choice. There are micro-transactions, but they're not necessary, and can be circumvented through daily challenges and ghost mode (use the pause menu, in-game menu, or hot-key, k, to see them).

Sniping and stealth are extremely satisfying. This is a [strike] tactical [/strike] [b] tacti-cool [/b] game, so learning how you position yourself for your goal, how you approach your goal, when to adapt, use of the resources you have (drone, rebels, and vehicles), how the game reacts to your actions, and [u] looking as badass as possible [/u] are essential. Driving is fun, SAM launchers are death, flying is fast, helicopters with weapons are easy mode, and [b] NEVER [/b] use bikes in perma-death mode.

[b] When Going Loud [/b]

Rate of fire, cover, and range are king (M4 + GL supremacy) in gunfights. Some weapon attachments are pointless, while others are nearly required to stay alive on higher difficulties. More bullets (bigger magazine / higher rate of fire) = more dead enemies and less bullets that could kill you. Anti-material/heavier weapons melt anything they shoot or spray at. Although, the most badass approach is always best, and the best looking gun always wins the gunfight.

[b] Good luck ghosts and happy hunting! [/b]

Ultimately it's too big and repetitive, BUT the fact remains that all the things you do in it are fun. The mechanics are fantastic. Sneakin, taggin, runnin, gunnin. They get fleshed out and developed even more in Breakpoint, which is the more advanced title in the series (and also the superior game), but Wildlands is still great fun and totally worthwhile. Big-picture, the mission variety and pacing has a Far Cry rhythm to it. I play solo - everyone says these games shine in co-op but I'm having a lot of fun with the ai bots since sync shot is so fun to execute and they are just always invisible and teleport to wherever you are. Ultimately the titles are similar enough that I'm coming back to finally complete this one after finishing BP - just because I want more of this style of fun gameplay. These are the kinda games that you just "have going" at any time whenever you want to scratch an action itch for a few missions. The story just kinda sends you around and does a fine enough job to convince you the mission is worth doing. But there could be a lot more story-wise here (another spot where BP outshines Wildlands). The two greatest open-world gun action RPGs in existence (imho)! Just need a Breakpoint in the post-apocalypse with discovery prioritized over the mission structure. Heh. This game has very firmly convinced me that the meta for having fun in the current year is Coop games with a dash of jenk.

It's still a Ubisoft title from 2017. Physics are buggy, menus are bad, you have to install Uplay to even get going and then deal with all that chicanery, and It takes a solid 5+ minutes to figure out how to party up nowadays.

But

After you deal with all that you actually have a fun, chill, and generally customizable experience that can be as serious or goofy as you please. Wanna take it waaaaaaaay too serious for what it is? Sure: crank up the difficulty, turn on to Tiers mode, and have at it. A stealthy, no-hud experience that will challenge your abilities and your sanity because (insert ubisoft bug here).
Wanna get a little silly? A little Goofy even? Play tactical barbie dolls for half an hour so you look like a thrift store massacre and play dress up to LARP as different countries or aesthetics (my favorites are Rhodesian SAF, British SAS, Crayon-Eaters, and Ted Kaczynski fan club.)

Stroll through Bolivia and just do CIA type jazz. Liberate the oil, communicate with rebel forces and provide them with better munitions, politely explain to journalists why they shouldn't have made that publication, and leave no witnesses (but it caps you out around 3 with a two ish minute cooldown so you're fine).

If you try to play this game alone you're missing out, big time. Even just getting one extra player (but don't play with randos) makes it exponentially more fun.

Oh, also the PvP is basically dead. Only way you'll get a game is custom matches

Overall rating: Still like an 8.75//10. It's jenky, it's goofy, it's better with a buddy, but above all else it's just fun.

This most underwhelming, open world, modern Ubislop piece of mid you could ever play. All you do is drive across the big boring ass map doing missions, picking up items, marking things and occasionally having a somewhat decent gunfight with enemies. The guns sound weak and the movement and aim feels clunky. I can't describe it very well but I get almost this feeling of motion sickness while playing because of how clunky it feels.

Strangely enough this game has some rather decent response mechanics with really satisfying hit effects for when you damage enemies and kill them. Plus there are bullet wounds, blood splatters on walls and even blood pools. But get this, dead bodies will despawn almost the moment you turn around if you walk more than 10 or so meters away from them. So there is virtually no aftermath after gunfights. I assume this is because Ubisoft was too lazy to implement a body pick up mechanic, you know that thing they had all the way back in fucking 2002 with Splinter Cell. The enemy AI are BRAINDEAD and you can easily take down an entire outpost without them even noticing you were there by just clicking on their heads with silenced weapons and snipers you get at the START of the game (On the hardest difficulty by the way). 

All this in tandem with the mediocre gunplay, long driving segments that only YOU can do because the AI teammates cannot drive and squad mechanics leads this game feeling so underbaked and unpolished. It's a shame really because conceptually it does not sound that bad but this is Ubisoft open world games we're talking about here. At the very least customization is halfway decent and you can make your character look really sick. I wouldn't say it isn't worth your money because you can get it for quite cheap. The issue is that this game simply isn't worth your time. Maybe you've got nothing else going on and don't really care about any sort of immersion or engaging mechanics and just want a stealth-power fantasy then maybe it ain't half bad.

It took me a little while to get use to the style of gaming but once I got it, it was a great ride all the way to the end.

I played TCGR Breakpoint first, had quite a lot of fun clearing out the map solo - both in realistic and normal modes.
I was pretty excited about playing Wildlands as well, especially that I was going to finish it with my friend in co-op - and so we did.
At first it was fun. We were trying to go full stealth mode, but often failed miserably. Soon we started to gain more resources and invested them in completely different play styles that complete each other, so we became more effective and started to progress faster. Clearing out camps and military bases, finding new equipment and hunting for convoys was all fun...for maybe 20 hours. Then the repetitive gameplay loop became a chore and we started to mindlessly fly from place to place, trying to finish the main storyline as fast as possible... and even then, it took as over 50 hours to complete (without DLCs).
But the pain started after reaching Tier One (which can be enabled or disabled at will). When it is disabled the enemies are half-blind, take some time to realize that you're around, even if you stand right next to them, and taking into account how many bad guys you fight, it is fine, even if a bit stupid. But then, after level 30 and activating Tier One mode, you will discover how botched the AI really is in this game, how primitive and lazy the programming is. After gaining a few levels, the enemies turn into cyborgs. 
Discovering you not only takes much less time, but the distance us much greater. Often the enemies discovered us through solid objects.
Furthermore they become tanky as hell, being able to survive a sniper shot in their chests (even when not armoured), but the worst part is, they always know where you are and act like they are connected by some kind of hive-mind, but the worst part is that they never miss their shots and as soon as you're in their unobstructed line of sight, they'll mow you down. Their aim works like an aimbot and jump right away from player to player. Add to that the unending of Unidad and stupid, unfair design of some tasks and you get nothing but frustration - either that or a feeling that you're losing progress and miss out on further character development by disabling Tier One.

Ghost Recon Wildlands, the tenth installment in the Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon series, takes players on a thrilling journey into the heart of the Bolivian drug trade. Released in 2017 by Ubisoft, this tactical shooter introduces a vast open-world setting, allowing players to immerse themselves in a gripping narrative while employing strategic gameplay.

The game's standout feature is its expansive open-world environment. Set in a stunningly detailed and diverse rendition of Bolivia, players are given the freedom to explore landscapes ranging from dense jungles to arid deserts. The sheer scale of the map provides an immersive playground for tactical operations, fostering a sense of realism and unpredictability in every mission.

In Ghost Recon Wildlands, players assume the role of an elite Ghost operative tasked with dismantling a powerful drug cartel. The narrative unfolds through a series of interconnected missions, each contributing to the overarching goal of destabilizing the cartel's operations. While the story may not break new ground, it serves as a compelling backdrop for the intense and strategic firefights that define the Ghost Recon experience.

The game's tactical gameplay mechanics shine in both single-player and cooperative modes. Players can choose to tackle missions solo with AI-controlled teammates or enlist the help of up to three friends for a cooperative multiplayer experience. The emphasis on careful planning, reconnaissance, and synchronized execution adds depth to the gameplay, rewarding those who approach missions with a thoughtful and strategic mindset.

Ghost Recon Wildlands boasts an impressive array of weaponry and equipment, allowing players to customize their loadouts to suit different playstyles. The game's skill tree system further enhances personalization, offering a sense of progression as players unlock new abilities and improve their Ghost's capabilities. This level of customization encourages experimentation, ensuring that no two players will approach missions in exactly the same way.

The visuals in Ghost Recon Wildlands are nothing short of breathtaking. The attention to detail in the game's environments, character models, and dynamic weather effects contributes to a visually stunning and immersive experience. From the sun-drenched landscapes to the tense night operations, the game's graphics play a pivotal role in conveying the atmosphere and tension of the covert operations.

While Ghost Recon Wildlands received praise for its engaging gameplay and expansive world, some critics noted occasional technical hiccups and repetitive mission structures. The AI, while generally competent, could at times exhibit inconsistencies in behavior. However, the game's post-launch support and updates addressed many of these issues, reflecting Ubisoft's commitment to refining and improving the player experience.

In conclusion, Ghost Recon Wildlands successfully marries the thrill of tactical military operations with the freedom of an open-world setting. Its vast landscapes, strategic depth, and cooperative gameplay make it a standout entry in the Ghost Recon series. Whether playing solo or with friends, Ghost Recon Wildlands offers an intense and rewarding experience for fans of tactical shooters and those seeking an immersive open-world adventure.

It is too bad that someone had to do the developer's job and make a first person mod for this game.  But now that one is available on Nexus, the game is definitely worth a play through.  Especially if you can get it for an 80% off sale!

Edit: Flying is terrible in this game.  I don't expect a MS Flight Sim, or even an Ace Combat, but this flying is worse than even the Far Cry's-- which until now I thought would be impossible--but the planes in Wildlands are a new UX low.  At least add an altimeter to the plane.  it couldn't be that hard as you already have it in the helicopter.

Edit2:   The main story line is LOADED with timers.  So your strategy goes out the window for a headlong rush to try to beat the stopwatch on the screen.  And to make it worse you never know when a timer will pop up, so you can't really perpare.  This artificial and lazy technique to increase difficulty is, IMO, extremely anti-immersive and extremely poor UX.   I won't be finishing the game and am just glad I got it for 80% off.

Note to developers:   Take a hint from the most popular open world game ever, Fallout.  There is NO TIMERS in the entire game, and the user can choose first or third person.  Or if you insist on your timers, then put them in optional side missions, like the latest Far Cry, rather than in the main story line.

game itself is great. But when you leave for a while, and next thing you know your signed out of the ubisoft starter thing, and it no longer recognizes that you even own the game...speaks for itself. Ive had this happen with every ubisoft game ive bought so i cant say im too surprised it happened but regardless.

You might find a lot of people in this review section saying the game's main downside is the fact that Ubisoft made it, and I agree completely; it's the one factor that stops this game from being a fantastic open-world FPS.

Don't get me wrong, this is still an absolute banger, but it didn't go without it's bumps in the road. Upon release, many glitches were prominent, which definitely stabbed the game's performance early on where it's most critical. But as time goes on, things got fixed, and people moved on to the next thing as the game got its repairs. This left it to not really blow up as much as what could be expected. I mean you look at the game firsthand and you hear glitches and Ubisoft, already a no-go, right?

What the game lacks in some functionality it makes up for in visual beauty. Yeah, you do need a decent rig to run it smoothly, but it's absolutely worth it. It still stuns me now, and I've tried RTX Minecraft. The lush forests, barren saltflats, and changing weather really bring this game to life.
There's LOTS, and I mean LOTS of information in the game about Bolivia itself which I find to be extremely appealing to have. Many games will take place in like France or something and not give you ANY information about the culture. That doesn't slide here. In the game, you're an operative in a country that isn't immediately in the mainstream media, so if you aren't familiar, the game gives you trivia. Post-war Germans living in the country, Death Road, JesÃºs Malverde, and more stories are able to be found. There are also PLENTY of files and dialogue on the main game story as well in case that's what you want to pay attention to, but none of said files and trivia are required to continue on. It's a respectful thing to do, and it shows the developers really went out of their way to understand Bolivian culture; it shows how much they really cared about the game, so it's nice to see.

The stealth in this game is fairly good, def could be better but pretty good. The game lacks in being able to drag bodies which is a pretty big letdown, but usually the AI is pretty easy anyways. The easiness was actually a complaint early on for the game, so Ubisoft added Extreme mode and Ghost Mode. Extreme mode meaning your body would seize if you breathed too much, and Ghost Mode meaning basically 2 shots without a revive and you gotta start over. All the way over. Like, back to the part where you're landing in the country, over. Talk about being careful. Still, can't drag bodies which is annoying and I really wish being able to hide in bushes was a bit more functional than it is as of writing, but the enemy on the right difficulty can still be scary at times which makes it all the more satisfying to do things right. When playing with friends, I like to have my friends infiltrate compounds while I post up as a sniper correcting any mistakes they make from 400+ meters away.

It would be a crime to not talk about the guns in a gun game. The guns are great in their models and customization. You can paint your guns solid colors, official camos, funny camos, whatever suits you. Then you can modify it to just how you like. Every Buchon has a custom gun you unlock too that reflects their personality. For example, one guy you capture builds submarines, so naturally his unlock is a gun made from sub parts. The sniper rifles were done really well in my opinion because every rifle has quite a different bullet drop, and since the landscape is huge, you have to pay attention to it a lot. I found myself testing different scopes with different rifles to see which was best, and started remembering where the range was on each set. It's very satisfying to get it right and pull off a 500+ meter shot.

The customization on the clothes as well is really good. The game gives you hundreds of options if you want to go with tactical clothes or more civilian-style like Nomad's base character. Of course, there's like 70 something different colors you can do for basically half or more of those clothing options too. When you're done with that, you can choose what patches you want to do on your backpack, baseball cap, shoulder-armor, etc. "Made in the 757" is a personal fav.

I'm a motorhead, so obviously I want the driving mechanics to be good. This game did okaaaay with that, but honestly better quite a few other games out there. Steering is pretty annoying, but the transmission mechanic is really good. You can hear the RPM climbing and, if you're smart, tap the throttle before it shifts to get a premature gearshift in the car. I'm glad they paid attention to that. What didn't go so well was the flying mechanics. The flying, like driving, is okaaaay, at least in classic mode. If you want to hit something in classic mode with weapons, forget it. It's basically impossible. Ubisoft tried to fix this issue with new flying mechanics but they found a way to realllllly fumble it. It's REALLY bad. Driving = eh, not bad | flying = pretty trash depending on what you're doing.

People in this review section have been talking about connection issues. While I haven't had to wait 20 minutes (yet) to go in-game, I do have a "connection error" every time I try to the load the game up. Not game-breaking, but quite a nuisance. I got a feeling this is just something Ubisoft did to mess things up like usual, so I can't be mad at the game for it,

My final verdict: 8.02/10, just barely got the 8.
The culture attention and visuals are fantastic. Gunplay, character/weapon customization and difficulty are great. The driving, stealth, and story is pretty good. The flying and the networking is meh. The fact that this is a Ubisoft game, meaning lootboxes and network issues, is bad. Just bad.

These other people are right for saying this game is better with friends, because without them it becomes a bit of a grind. Is it worth the $50? Ehh, with friends, for the most part, but definitely try to snag a sale first. I've made some good memories with this game, and I've played through GR: Breakpoint after this too (that game is basically just a sequel btw). That game had a lot of stuff I wanted in this game, but if I had the tough choice to either do one or the other,

I'd go to the Wildlands.

Playing this title for as long as I have has been the biggest regret in my recent memory.

For every fun moment and interesting game-play element there are 4-5 different things that just completely suck the joy from this game.
There are still technical issues this long after release, and the AI (both teammates and enemies) is a complete disappointment.
The breaking of the camels back was ghost mode which is a one-life-game-mode. Permadeath and immediate cloud save of your failed attempt...

In any other game this would be a cool challenge. Except this game which has no predictability, consistency or logical reasoning for a player to consistently avoid death.

I'll even admit to keeping backups of my saves for this mode, to only have the entirety of it being completely fucked up by Ubisoft and their decision to save anytime you are downed (you can get revived by your teammates which is not a death scenario) EXCEPT the AI was too stupid and inconsistent to actually assist the player.

This is the hallmark of Ubisoft games. Its a million great ideas, decent depth and, good concepts bogged down by terrible execution, stupid decision making, and development pitfalls that creates a dog water, piece of crap title.

I wish I could regain the amount of time spent on this dog-water but sadly that's impossible. 

Uninstalling this turd is equivalent to ending a toxic relationship. The immediate relief and freedom is amazing. 

Better yet, never purchase this game at all and you'll save yourself from this trash.

All the "good" moments are not worth the garbage this game hands you in droves.

-UPDATE:
The final mission to cap off the entire game is an underwhelming, half brained, complete nonsense turd.
Its not difficult in the challenge, requiring smart play and good "tactics" instead its just throw every enemy at the player, every second, without pause and put them on a time limit to complete a "GET TO THIS POINT" objective.

There are a lot of cool things about this game but quite a few utterly ridiculous things.  The first is you must be online with the Ghost Recon servers to play the game.  If your internet goes down or Ghost Recon's servers go down, you are out of luck.  It's just the games way of letting you know that you don't own it.  Then, it is utterly ridiculous is that everything on your weapon from sights, to magazine capacity, are upgrades you have to find on the battlefield.  This means for the first while you are stuck with Vietnam Era 20 round magazines for your rifle, and you have the lamest kit that only let's you carry 5 magazines.  These two things are so ignorant that I just cannot recommend this game, which is too bad because I was really looking forward to this when it came out.

I was hoping this would be a strategic game with tactical battles but there is no strategy at all.  None of the targets you pick have any effect on the battlefield.  Outposts are repopulated within minutes of you defeating them.  It is only a check the box exercise.  Missions you fail are immediately reset so you can do it over again.  Some, way back at the beginning that makes the tactical part of the game a complete drudgery.  The enemy never comes looking for you.  There are no hunter killer teams.  If you are spotted the enemy will call for help but help gets there WAY too quickly confirming that enemies endlessly spawn just out of range.

So much of the game is scripted and though parts are fun it just reminds me the game is playing me.  Failed missions have no impact on the game because they just reset.

The major issue with Wildlands is that it isn't a stealth shooter. Don't get me wrong, it has stealth shooter sections, and those are by far the best parts of the game, but that is fundamentally not how the developers seem to intend for you to play.

There are simply too many story missions where you try to go in with stealth, and the game forcefully causes you to be detected. This leads to having to shoot everything that moves, while every enemy taking potshots at you from behind cover.

In mission when you die, you have to redo the first bit of the mission, then fly a helicopter in a straight line for 5 to get back to the part you died at. I'm not sure if travelling long distances is supposed to build suspense, but it doesn't, it causes me to literally watch movies while holding a key down on my keyboard.

Combined with Unidad spawning infinite enemies, like GTA, except in GTA it is punishment for killing random civilians, where in Wildlands it is punishment for standing on the side of the road.

Not to mention, there are way too many escort and extraction missions.

All in all it is impossible for me to recommend this game. Go play Rainbow Six Vegas 2 if you want a good shoot-em-up game. If you like stealth, try Hitman. I would recommend Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter 2, but good luck getting that game to run on a modern PC. Or maybe just heavily mod Fallout 4 until it plays like a Ghost Recon game.

EDIT: Also, the ending is bugged. If you 100% the game, it will give you the bading ending and say something along the lines of "Congratulation, you've completed 100% of the game. Now complete 100% of the game for a different ending". Apparently the developers assumed no one would be stupid enough to 100% the game and didn't bother testing for this eventuality. You can replay the mission to get the correct ending, but that at point you might as well just watch the ending on youtube and save your time.

I grew up playing the original Ghost Recon on the original Xbox with all its expansions, plus Ghost Recon 2 and Rainbow Six 3. I skipped the rest of the Ubi/Ghost Recon games until this one. This game was bastardized to be more mainstream or lack of buttons on controller. 

At the time of this posting, I bought the game on deep sale about a week ago. For the initial honeymoon phase of the first 10-20 hours in I was having a lot of fun in co-op and solo, but the more I played the more I dislike it. At the time of this at 78 hours in I'm slogging through it with repetitive side quests to improve my chances of success.  

For starters, 6 years after release and it still employs Denuvo with the capability to degrade performance with Easy Anti-Cheat on top? Why? Anyone that wanted to torrent the game already has years ago, not to mention doesn't have to deal with UPlay. 

There's no option to play fully in 1st person and no manual leaning system. There are FOV mods to mitigate this but no manual leaning system is a massive blow. I do understand that this is a stealth game and I can lean around corners and walls when I ADS, but I'm exposing myself to be shot at by more enemies in a weaker position. The older games on the original xbox from 15 years ago at the time of release had this feature. Why do I need to mash 4 to switch between half a dozen throwables? Why can't I split these grenades up on 5 through 0 on the keyboard? Or better yet categorizing them from flashbangs, frags, mines, and other explosives. 

Despite having the game on Ultra settings, enemies on solo disappear past 600 meters. What is the point in having these high power scopes when we can't even fully utilize them? In addition killing the cartel bosses makes no difference exploring the world. 

The friendly AI is both powerful and stupid all at the same time. You get access to the powerful sync shot with up to 3 charges. Inside vehicles they are fine and always ready to shoot back. But I've experienced a few times when we are in the middle of a fight the friendly AI(s) don't even acknowledge the enemy shooting at them, the same issue as in Ready or Not.

"I'm crouched in the dense underbrush, the humid night air thick with tension and the acrid scent of the jungle. As I prepare to infiltrate another cartel base, the experience is nothing short of exhilarating.

The Ghosts and I had been tracking this particular cartel base for weeks, watching from afar as the criminals executed their nefarious deeds. Tonight, the time has come to put an end to their reign of terror. I'm armed with my trusty M40A51, the cool metal grip reassuring in my hands. My comrades, Weaver, Holt, and Midas, have my back, and the thrill of coordinated teamwork is palpable. We're all players in a meticulously crafted symphony of destruction.

The base is sprawling, lit up like a Christmas tree. Our objective: eliminate the cartel boss and extract vital intel. I rely on my drone, a handy tool in our arsenal, to scout the enemy positions. As the night closes in around us, I mark enemy snipers, armored soldiers, and spot a mortar that could mean our end here. The cartel's defenses are no joke.

Silently, we move forward. The moonlight casts eerie shadows through the jungle canopy as we approach the base. The stealth aspect of our is where we truly shine. We take down a couple of guards with well-placed shots, their deaths shrouded in mystery. The tension mounts with each silent kill, and I can feel the adrenaline pumping through my veins.

However, the element of surprise is short-lived. Our stealthy approach inevitably devolves into chaos as our presence is detected. Bullets fly, explosions rock the base, and alarms blare. The base comes alive with cartel soldiers hunting us down like wild animals. The heat of the firefight is breathtaking, and the sound of bullets whizzing past and explosions is as exhilirating as it gets.

In the midst of the chaos, we locate our target - the cartel boss. The intense firefight becomes a game of cat and mouse as we hunt him down through the twisting labyrinth of shipping containers and buildings. It's a heart-pounding experience, each step more dangerous than the last.

After an intense firefight, the cartel boss falls, his reign of terror over. With his death, the base is practically ours. I can't help but feel a sense of accomplishment as we extract the vital intel we came for and help the allied rebels into the base."

Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon: Wildlands is a breathtaking journey, an open-world sandbox of military strategy and tactical warfare. From the sprawling landscapes to the realistic gunplay and the richly detailed narrative, it's a game that immerses you in the life of a Ghost. If you love intense combat, a compelling story, and the thrill of battling the odds in a hostile, drug-fueled world, Wildlands is the game you've been waiting for.

So grab your gear, rally your squad, and step into the shoes of a Ghost. The war against the Santa Blanca cartel is calling, and in Wildlands, you'll feel the adrenaline, the tension, and the thrill of the silent shadows like never before.

I appreciate this is late to the debate, but I have to say this game will make you unhappy as a solo player. 

If you turn off HUD displays you aren't told what weapon or attachment you collected - in the weapons  menu! The loadout doesn't tell you the most obvious stuff (zoom settings of scope) You cant fly higher than 1ft because of SAM. I won't even go into how useless your fireteam is. The laziness of the placing of intel is annoying and adds zero value to the gameplay (yet all areas have 14 to collect), and it is obvious the devs ended up shoving two in many places - so pointless. The response time from the enemy is overwhelmingly fast and is ridiculous - you silence an alarm but helicopters turn up anyway. Don't even get me started on Unidad superhuman powers. Why do they have a problem with the cartel if Unidad are all robocops? The civilians walk around in firefights passively and disinterested. The game physics are slow, unresponsive and not accurate (playing on 13th gen with RTX4080 - so not me). I had to stop playing because not risking mashing my new beautiful Lenovo Legion 7i for this POS game.

I can understand why the Bolivian Government had a problem with this game - it wholly misrepresents their country but personally I think that the reason they got so insulted ... is because if you are going to try and tackle a difficult topic like South American corruption in a game ... make it a good game, but this - this is so bad it makes the country, it's people and it's illicit drug industry look stupid. I find nothing makes people angrier than making them feel stupid. You can do a lot to a person if you are respectful, but make them feel stupid and you will find out quickly how even the most oppressed can rise up and f you in the a.

I uninstalled this within days of purchase. I appreciate the industry has great pressures on dev leadtimes and logistics. I appreciate that this game is some years old (I actually played Breakpoint to completion before buying wildlands on sale 80% off and whilst also underwhelmed by Breakpoint it is at least better in all respects I listed above and would still recommend buying at a discount if you get the chance).

 That Wildlands it is still being sold for over Â£35 is shocking to me. If I had spent that much you can bet your bottom dollar I would have demanded a refund. As it is, I am not going to flog a dead horse and accept it for what it is - a troubled game (as so many are these days). 

I have played so many open world games as they are/were my jam. I am at heart a masochist. This time however I simply asked "why am I doing this to myself?" and uninstalled.

I am not attacking the devs (I take a knee and raise my fist in the air for them) but I am attacking the industry and it's financiers: they are the reason so many potentially excellent games get released without finesse and thus break the 4th wall for the consumer.

This is my first negative review of a game. I have played many bad games that lacked for so many reasons. I think the reason that this game received my full aggression is that it made me feel stupid and I don't like that. I suspect others will feel the same way and so I say - do not buy!

Ghost Recon Wildlands: The Good, The Bad, and Better Than Breakpoin

First things first, let's talk about how it compares to Breakpoint. Now, I don't want to throw shade, but let's be real â Wildlands is like the big brother Breakpoint wishes it could be. It's more open, more engaging, and just...better.

Now, onto the nitty-gritty - gameplay. It's fantastic, no two ways about it. The freedom to tackle missions in any order and the ginormous open world to explore is a blast. You can go all tactical, sneaking around like a ninja, or go in guns blazing, and both ways are satisfying.

But here's the kicker - it can get repetitive. Clearing out yet another cartel outpost, stealing another chopper, it starts to feel like a Groundhog Day scenario after a while. But, hey, isn't that what we signed up for in a sandbox game?

What's great about Wildlands is that it feels like you're playing with your buddies. The AI team members are surprisingly competent (and you don't have to worry about them stealing your snacks).

The story? Well, it's not exactly Oscar-worthy, but it's enough to keep you moving from one breathtaking locale to another. You're on a mission to dismantle a drug cartel, and let's be honest, it's a pretty solid excuse to explore the stunning landscapes of Bolivia.

Now, I can't finish this review without mentioning the vehicles. From dirt bikes to choppers, you've got an impressive garage at your disposal. The driving physics are surprisingly solid, and there's no greater joy than catching some air off a cliff in a stolen sports car.

So, in a nutshell, Ghost Recon Wildlands is an action-packed sandbox, a little bit repetitive but hella fun. It's the better sibling compared to Breakpoint, offering an open-world playground with plenty of toys to keep you entertained. If you're into tactical shooters with a dash of chaos, you've found your game.
