This game just disappoints me. Seriously, it's just disappointing. I've played GR Future Soldier, Breakpoint and now this...

To explain the reason why I *HEAVILY* suggest against buying this game, I'll put my points as to what I liked, what I don't like, and my reaction to the positive reviews.

The good:

Vehicle driving feels more fun, being able to drift around corners and give chase to lieutenants can be exhilarating!

The variety in guns is acceptable

Being able to help the rebel resistance to gain access to support options like rebel mortar fire is really interesting and cool, allowing you to plan for bigger assaults

----------------------------------------

The mediocre:

Call me crazy, but I think the gun mechanics are very mediocre, it feels like most of the time, I'm slinging bits of hardened playdough at my enemies, not damage wise, but the feel of the gun feels off, like battlefield 4 kind of gunplay, where the guns don't feel satisfying to fire

Along with this, there is gun customisation, which is okay, however the actual customisation of guns is limited, for example, to get a grenade launcher, you need to... put skill points into it? It rubs me the wrong way and is more of a personal preference, however comparing it to previous games, the customisation feels mediocre, or even a couple steps back

Character movement in this game is passable, it's nice how fluid getting behind and coming out of cover can be, however most of the time it feels like you're running through wax and it never feels like you're getting anywhere fast enough

Lack of specialists means that everyone feels the same. There's no difference between two maxed out players apart from their weaponry, which just feels bland, especially compared to Breakpoint. It's not for everyone, but not having access to unique abilities or tradeoffs makes the game very stale.

The character customisation is flat as a pancake, you have a choice between seven different hairstyles which are shared between both genders, different faces that you can't change the colours of, so I ended up just making Foap from MW3

----------------------------------------

The Bad/Controversial:

You are a regular soldier. On the surface, this may be a bit baffling, however comparing Wildlands to Future Soldiers is like comparing a generic armyman to someone in the spec ops, you're meant to be top class soldiers with futuristic equipment on you, allowing you to take care of situations quietly or be able to assault in ways that completely overwhelms your enemies, instead you're just Joe. You have your rifle, secondary, pistol and drone, and that's it. No stealth technology, no door busting gadgets, not even a throwable scanner of some description, and it's just.. empty. If you're going into this game with the expectation of being an actual member of the Ghost Recon squad, I'm sorry to say, you're just some standard army riflemen.

The map... by god the map. Your minimap is something you'll look at, purely for the purpose of finding materials for the rebels or for collectibles. Is it above or below your location? I don't know, it's just there, which makes it frustrating. Does it tell you where possible entrances are? Nope. Maybe it can give hints as to nearby people who haven't been identified? Nope. This makes looking at the minimap pointless, unless you wish to run around to give the rebels some supplies, speaking of..

The rebels, this system, while cool in theory, is just wasted potential. Most of what they can do is specifically useful when you're assaulting an area loud, however, you're Ghodt Recon, you're meant to be stealthy, which throws all of the cool stuff such as the mortar barrage, squad of rebels, etc out the window because calling any of them in will blow your cover

Guns, their customisation, the lack of sorting options, just baffles me completely. Bearing in mind I have all the DLC, the most useful weapon I've had is the rapid fire crossbow, which will one shot anyone, pierces so you can do a 2 for 1 deal, is always silent and hardly has any drop, meaning you can go on entire mutder sprees considering it fires as fast as it reloads, whilst holding 60 bolts, I have never felt like it was good using a gun as the inaccuracy modifiers and recoil of the gun were too penalising compared to using the crossbow, nevermind the lack of customisation compared to Breakpoint, which came out before this

Vehicles suck, the only vehicle you'll ever need is the minigun helicopter as driving takes too long with all the mountains, and the minigun eill not alert enemies outside a certain bubble, so you can spray to your hearts content at all the little dots down below

The lack of life in this game feels cheap, sure people drive by or are walking by the road, however I have never once stopped by the road because something caught my eye, as you're fast travelling then just going from point A to point B, at least in Breakpoint there were constant patrols, items to collect, resources to gather, in Future Soldier exploring would reward you with collectibles, guns, what have you, but EVERYTHING you need to actually progress is highlighted in all the different towns, which just kills off anything outside them, sadly

There is backstory to the characters, but they purely come from the collectibles, so if you ignore collectibles and just go straight into killing the folk, you won't even know stuff about the people you killed, which changes... nothing, the fact that they don't taunt you, or know about your existence after dlaughtering their dedicated sector feels jarring and unreal, I'm more than certain if you wiped off an entire group from a real life cartel, they wouldn't take it lying down.

My biggest grudge against ANYONE who says that "Oh yeah, playing it with friends will make it better" Is just a blitering idiot. Any game with multiplayer instantly gets better when you can have friends in it, however, if the core game is such a terrible dtate of empty, then what reason would YOU have to continue? Compare this to deep rock galactic, in which yes, you can play this with friends, playing it solo feels great to play as well as coop, and sometimes EVEN BETTER!


So riddle me this Batman, if this game is bland, empty, a point to point mission slog, with a story that probably is better left uncared for than you actually paying attention to it, by playing 3rd person Call of Duty, why would you want this game? If you desperately need your open world multiplayer game itch scratched, go play breakpoint, it has a much, MUCH better system than Wildlands.

----------------------------------------

Tldr: Game has nothing of value to give, multiplayer games are always more fun with friends, if you want futuristic gadgets with a more fun combat system, go play Breakpoint, it's cheaper and doesn't require as hefty of a system to look as good :)

Ghost Recon is dead, And Ubisoft keeps violating it's dead corpse.

I picked up Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands during a Steam sale as a surprise gift for my friends, and it turned out to be one of the best gaming decisions I've ever made. This game is a treasure trove of unforgettable memories, and it's held up incredibly well over time.

Even in the gaming world where new titles constantly clamor for attention, Wildlands still shines. Its polished graphics and immersive open-world environment feel just as fresh today as when we first dove in. The attention to detail in the sprawling landscapes, from dense jungles to arid deserts, is simply stunning.

But what truly makes Wildlands a standout experience is its co-op play. Playing with friends turned the game into a rollercoaster of hilarity, tactical brilliance, and occasional friendly fire mishaps. Whether we were coordinating helicopter assaults on drug cartel compounds or hijacking convoys, every mission was an adventure.

The outposts and objectives could sometimes seem repetitive, but when you're laughing your head off with buddies while trying to stay stealthy, it hardly matters. And speaking of variety, the game's high weapon customizability and the abundance of character perks added depth and replayability, keeping us hooked for hours on end.

Ghost Recon Wildlands isn't just a game; it's a canvas for unforgettable co-op stories. It's a testament to the power of friendship, teamwork, and the joy of conquering challenging missions together. If you're looking for a game that stands the test of time and offers endless opportunities for cooperative fun, look no further than Ghost Recon Wildlands. It's an experience that I'll cherish for years to come.

Suffers from some of the most braindead design flaws you could have in any kind of shooter. 
- Your companions are near useless, and only ever function right when you are directly commanding them and not focused on defending yourself.
- Enemy ability to detect you is near supernatural 
- You're a tier 1 spec ops operators that can't afford to start with rifle mags that can hold a standard 30 round capacity
- You can't use your parachute any time that it matters.
- Airplane missions are impossible because the controls are garbage and your companions can literally bump into the wing when exiting and make them explode (not an exaggeration, that's actually how poorly calibrated the physics and impact settings are). 
- All difficulty is cheaply artificial due to suicidal enemy AI, and them being able to spawn wherever they want. The rules of the game only really apply to you. 
- Ammo is plentiful to the point that I've never run out, making brute force almost always the best course of action. 

There is a good game buried deep deep beneath the absolute absence of quality control, but the problems with it surface so constantly that I've never been able to go a single day without being infuriated and having to take a break. The sequel overhauled a lot of these problems, but did so without replicating the tone and feel that made Wildlands compelling to come back to, resulting in a completely different game that doesn't even resemble the same franchise.

It's basically GTA with focus on combat and stealth. It means that it's an open world game where you can do whatever you want. You can choose to go with the main story or just have fun with the side quests. You can also try to find all collectibles which can help you in various ways.

The progression system is quite unique. You'll have to find predefined items and tag them. You'll get certain points by doing that. Then you can use those points to level up. There are a wide variety of skills that you can progress in. Each is quite unique also. You can choose to boost your combat skill, enhance your drone, or improve your stealth skills.

In most case, you'll prefer stealth approach for all of your missions. It's because you can only take several hits from bullets before you die. A compromise between realism and game aspect.

In short, I bought this game with all the DLC. It's very fun and quite addictive.

We need to have both the steam launcher and the ubisoft launcher open and set ourselves to online. Then we need to make sure we both get the online notice after launching the game. After that I should be able to invite my husband to my game in one of several ways. The most consistent has been inviting him through the ubisoft launcher once I've started a gaming session, although lately I've had better luck inviting him from the game menu. If you're having trouble, snap three times with your left hand and do a spin counterclockwise, followed by four taps of your right toes and blink in a left, right, left, right, right pattern, and that should do the trick. TL;DR This game is like the best cupcake you've ever had, if someone took a shit on top of it.

Honestly you *should* play it, but every time I have fun, its often partnered with equal measures of frustration due to poorly implemented or unpolished systems,as well as bugs and other annoyances.

Some grievances:

 - Enemy AI is either complete idiot behavior or its actively cheating and sees you through walls. No matter where you are on the map, if the detection status changes to hunted/engaged/etc, the enemy will beeline toward your location and often has zero reason to even know your location. Body found at a location you already rotated away from? They know your current one, and you get to move AGAIN. Silently kill someone while they're alone and nobody else is around but you're already being hunted? Boom, they know your current location again like 70% of the time. *This isn't about easy or hard*, its about logical sense. Logical behavior. Its easy to mow down whole bases but that's boring as hell, and the stealth inconsistencies ruin a ton of potential fun. Meanwhile they're one of the only other creative options.

 - Because of the above AI bullsh!t, you are either in a firefight or are perfectly hidden, and very little inbetween is possible. If you're suspected or detected, you have to wait and Kite the AI around until they stop, instead of them logically following any normal reason to investigate anything. The game sees you at all times, which is fine, but does a PISS poor job of pretending it doesn't when it shouldn't.

 - Vehicle spawns are absolutely horrible and frustrating. Firstly, the most useful vehicle, the bike, isn't even available despite a HELICOPTER being available when you max out the ability to spawn vehicles. Secondly, when you do spawn vehicles, they game puts them in completely different area codes for zero fucking reason. Roleplay-wise your rebel contact delivers these vehicles to you, meanwhile I could be in a town that has one area full of enemies, and the dumbass drops my helicopter or armored car in the cloud of fucking enemies. Very smart, very realistic, very convenient.

 - The occasional on-rails-but-you-get-to-trial-and-error-find-the-rails story missions. Most are fine, even well made! But some are just purely unnecessary in terms of wasting time, and patience. For example, the  Silent Spade Mission with the helicopter segment (which I completed btw).

 - Enemies often do this ducking/sidestepping animation during gunfights, as if they hear gunshots and reflexively stumble out of the way. It always happens AFTER you fire on them, and it always essentially gives them an "oops that didn't actually happen" card to play while engaging them. What this means is while you're returning fire they can randomly just stop taking damage for a second, while things like detection still keep on ticking away against your favor. Edit: adding to this as I've noticed more, 

 - Inconsistent bullet damage to enemies when they're beginning to detect/have detected you vs when you're undetected. When undetected you can 1-2 shot most enemies even if you aim between the head and torso. When detected enemies occasionally decide to take upwards of 3 extra shots before they go down. Some things like snipers and machine guns tend to not suffer from this.

 - [Admittedly a small complaint] The Grenade/items UI system. Theres grenades, mines, c4, diversion lures, a flare gun, etc. And rather than make a system thats easy to use, you have to either spam 4 to cycle through it, or remember its cooresponding number key as a hotkey. Just make 4 a gear wheel with the locked/unlocked options on it. It would be so much easier.


In conclusion Id rather be playing MGSV but that games map is more boring, and has no civilians. I'm gonna keep playing this game and wish the things I've listed could be addressed, but since its Ubisoft I know it won't be. And that alone is why I think they deserve the thumbs down.

Note to self, do give a game a chance before making a review. I first reviewed this game after 10 hours and nearly gave up on it.  It does take about 12 hours to get into it as the control system is quite hard to master.  If you do buy it bear this in mind. Now I am over a hundred hours in but its still more like pulling teeth than enjoying yourself.  I did manage to finish the single player on easy. I am trying again on normal but I die much more often making if very slow.

The game is one of the slowest games to load that I have ever played.  Far cry and AC Valhalla are slow but this one is much slower. And when you get killed, which is pretty often you could make yourself a snack or go get yourself a beer while it loads again.  And don't don't even try fast travel; its quicker to run to your destination than to wait for it to load. Its not my machine, its the fact that it goes out to servers at Ubisoft and this can take upto 5 minutes

Secondly its almost impossible to be a ghost. The bad guys have 20-20 night vision and take about a second to spot you.  They can also hit you from 200 meters away with pinpoint accuracy.  In Normal mode this means you have a second to get out of the line of fire.  In advanced mode its be seen, be dead.  More often than not you move out of one line of fire directly into another.

In single player your squad is dumb as shit.  Your AI colleagues are mostly a waste of time in a fire fight. They never stay close to you so that when you need reviving its just a minute of waiting on the ground while they find you, put the silencer on their gun, take it of again and then decide to revive you often while leaving the guy that shot you completely alone.  They also let people creep up on you; they hardly ever watch your back.

And then some of the missions are just random.  Parachute into a base, kill all the bad guys without getting noticed, fly out with a helicopter and then suddenly have to fight  5 helicopters all of which can shoot you down in one shot.  Fail, then rinse and repeat.   There is no skill, its just sheer luck if you make it to the end. 

The terrain is very tedious and difficult to move across.  The game could do with some AC style parkour skills.  Several times I have had to resort to fast travel to get out of a hole that I am trapped in.

It tries to be Just Cause meets Sniper Ghost Warrier 2.  It fails on both counts.  In Just Cause the vehicles work.  In this game all vehicles are skittish and random.  The helicopters fall out of the sky unless you keep pressing up, the cars might as well be roller skates as none of the wheels are connected to the ground, they just pivot around the centre.  In Just Cause I almost never died.  You can always get out of trouble using the grappling hook then regroup and go again.  In this piece of trash if your vehicle dies then you are dead; If you get spotted by Unidad you are dead.  

There are a million different weapons with a million different combinations of add-ons and yet they are all the same.  Its been proven that the damage stats don't matter.  Similarly for the costumes. These options are like a pencil with no lead - pointless.

Get through the first few hours however and you will start earning skills.  These make the game more enjoyable indeed playable.  I have just gone back and done a "protect the radio" mission that was impossible 5 hours in and is now possible thanks to all of the upgrades. Even now, some of the things are hilarious like your teammate trying to walk through a moving train and getting run over mid battle.

I think the worst problem though is having played stealth shooters including the Tom Clancy ones for perhaps 20 years this one is so generic as to have lost something.  I could be playing Farcry 5 or Just Cause 3.  Its so much harder to play in stealth mode that I gave up wheras in previous incarnations it was always possible. 

If you are a fan of the series then you might find it a refreshing change. or you may, like me, find it a sell-out.

Great game, until you try to play it. The AI range from brain-dead to eagle-eyed wall hax dead-eyed shots. Alert 1 AI and every AI enemy knows exactly where you are and what you are doing as long as you remain in alert status, anywhere you go in the world. 

Try to play this game tactically to take out the AI carefully? Nope. 
AI are spawned within your operating area. Sometimes directly behind you (don't forget they instantly are locked on and firing). Sometimes kill an Enemy and another spawns in it's place... notices the dead body... and immediately all AI know what happened. 
Okay, so you can get in a fire fight and shoot your way out? Nope. 
The AI never... never needs to reload. So 100% accurate. 100% awareness. Infinite magazine rounds. You die. Replay the mission - from the absolute beginning. No way to skip those intro cut scenes that you watch 12-20 times (but you can skip the end of mission cut scenes). 

The AI can see through all trees and bushes but you cant. Don't forget you can get killed behind over. The bullets seem to curve or be guided. You can get shot behind concrete walls because the AI can shoot about 5 feet through the edge of any wall. You can't. 

Sometimes, the mission involves an AI character that needs to stay alive for you to interrogate. Well, he is often surrounded by shooting AI. So that's difficult. Sometimes, the AI will accidentally blow something up and kill the Mission AI - you start over from the absolute beginning. Other times, you have to talk to the Mission AI. Does the outside world pause? Nope. The Enemy continues as normal game play. Terrible when you have to stop talking to the Mission AI, kill all the Enemies (which will return shortly), and then RESTART the Mission AI dialogue from the introduction!!! 

This game could be great. It has a ton of things to explore. Fun guns. Decent movement mechanics and vehicles. But the mission structure and the AI just ruin every cool moment and fun thing about this game.

By far, one of the best games for a long time - probably eclipsing the Sniper Elite series.  It is reminiscent of Far Cry 2 where the world is huge, and what's more, you can go absolutely everywhere within it.  You chose your path to the ultimate confrontation, and the weapon selection is again, huge.  Weapon sounds are not that brilliant, but that's completely liveable with.

No game is perfect though.  Brilliant as Wildlands is, there are some very annoying parts that are unavoidable.  Missions that are time dependant that can get very repetitive due to the insufficient amount of time give.  Missions that have three or four parts to them that have no save point, and return you to the first part if you end up killed.  it's a relief to get those missions out of the way - but there are not that many of them.

You can chose just which missions to take on that are not story related - side ops that contribute to your ability to expand your characters capabilities.  And there are hundreds of these - no way you need to complete them all.  I did a huge chunk of them, and ended up finishing the first complete run through of the game in over 250 hrs.  Again, it's not necessary, but you get the most out of the game if you take on rebel ops that increase your abilities.  

The missions generated are not boring or too similar.  With Far Cry 2, it became all too easy after a while, and the missions chosen looked all too familiar.  Not with Wildlands - the world is even bigger, but this time the missions - even the side missions - have real contrast.

It does become a little easier once you develop your character's abilities.  Vehicle drop offs are a must - and it becomes more helpful if you can ask for an armoured car or a helicopter for some missions.  Weapon upgrades - loads of them.  However, I did find that there were limited weapons that could have grenade launchers attached.  A weapon with a grenade launcher is going to make your life so much easier.  I've played this first run through with weapon suppressors on the sniper rifle, assault rife and handgun.  It makes sense - but the next challenge would be to try a run through with no silenced weapons.

There are two possible end cut scenes - you have to complete the game once to generate the second ending. 

On a down side, there is one really bad bug that has not been resolved since the game's launch.. The first El Gato mission is seriously bugged if you are playing as a single player - the bad guy just doesn't appear so you can't take him out and therefore you can't progress.  The only way I found to get around this is to play this one mission as a co-op mission - let your team mates do the necessary - the mission gets finished - then revert back to the single player mode.  I've discovered that this bug has been around for years now - and it's really disappointing to find that Ubisoft still haven't fixed it.

That aside, this is one of the few games around that are worth the purchase price.  Loads of gameplay, and real challenges.  For all the faults I've mentioned, it's worth it.  Enjoy.

This game is very frustrating in many aspects. I do NOT recommend it.

The Pros:
- A good thing I can see in this game is the stealth that it includes. The stealth is very cool.
- Another good thing is the character customization and the weapon customization.
These 2 were all the good things I can see. Nothing else

The Cons:
- The controls are very VERY frustrating. The Helicopters are VERY hard to control. The ground vehicles sometimes WON'T turn left nor right.
- The NPCs that need to get extracted sometimes get bugged. Some other times they even hide under destroyed vehicles making them unable to be moved by the player. At the same time you might be fighting against a whole army and of course you can't leave without the prisoner because he is, of course, under the vehicles.
- The enemies Have AIM BOT. They almost NEVER miss!
- Random Enemy NPC spawning at bases that I have already started invading. (Even if you do neutralize the new spawn, it WILL SPAWN after a few seconds AGAIN and at the same spot!!!).
- Launching the game is quick...... But after entering the menu, choosing ->"Continue Campaign" and the ->"Launch in Offline" takes AGES.
- Sometimes you might find yourself reaching a base and then a Random Spawn of Enemy vehicles enters play and gets you from behind.
- Other times the drone won't be called out. It just won't!!!

Very unpolished and lacking real substance. 

-The helicopter blades don't kill enemies/people yet break against terrain (TIP: Try bouncing ontop of an enemy heli with your own to break their blades. Absolutely cash money, plus you dodge their gunfire)

-ALWAYS online, regardless of single player or not. Plus Ubisoft may delete your account and thus, your games if you dont play for ~6 months? 

-You can't jump.  

-New guns and attachments are unlocked by exploring and retrieving them in crates, a fair system. However, you can freely change your loadout wherever you are, in combat, in mission, 3000 feet in the air. No real need to "plan" or optimize loadouts

-Because attachments and weapons are so sparse, you really suffer in the beginning. Need a sniper? Use a FAL. SMG? FAL. CQC? FAL! Theres no benefit or any real need for other guns beyond different scopes. 

-Sometimes you need to interrogate someone, but they have a gun. Theres's no less than lethal tools to subdue someone... even grabbing them and "knocking them out" counts as a KILL. Lazy. 

+Realistic bullet ballistics and customizations do help make a gun feel like yours

-Vehicles are VERY loose/touchy and will easily toss you off a cliff
+Motorcycles are borderline impossible to fall off of as a result.

-Im ~18 hours in as of writing this, but after killing 3 buchons under an Underboss, this just getting kind of tiring. Sure, each mission is different and each boss has a "persona/unique" thing about them, but it's the same stuff. Find gold folder, do mission. Repeat ~5 times, go kill them. Buchon dead, congrats! Theres only 17 more, to do over again... and again... and again. 

-The missions fails are VERY brutal, borderline kicking you back to the start if you fail. Did you drive a box truck halfway across the map, clear a compound, deliver it, and fail because a patrol vehicle spotted you? Do it again, I wasnt looking. 

~The map is large, and each country has a feel to it? The map feels alive yet, so vacant and repetitive. Let me know when you find the "Mayor's Office" building that has the central large stairs and 2 sets to the left and right on the second floor to the third. 
+The HEAT MAP idea is a very cool feature, but a cleared providence still has cartel there, and some cartel control areas have heaps of rebels just driving around or patrolling. They could've had the map turn red vs green vs purple and focus troops or rebels there? But no, its just an overlay, that doesnt update live or reflect anything youve done beyond where youve traveled... which the normal map does anyways! What a waste. 


TL:DR; its a giant sandbox with stuff sprinkled in it. That's a lot of games broken down but, you're in Bolivia as a secret crew that drives around and kills endless cartel members. Missions can be completed in any order and thus have no real tension or "story" besides building your way up the chain. 

It has no real substance and is more of a time occupier than something you invest your time in and feel GOOD playing. Hell, go play Far Cry 3. Its similar but way better.

Great game, but more bugs than a biblical locust storm. I cannot understate how fun it is or how many laughs I've had with friends over it. 10/10 recommend, but read ahead for some issues especially if you use 11.

I like to give older games the benefit of the doubt because I run Windows 11 and not everything is optimized for it. While none of the issues that I have are game breaking per say, when they add up it becomes obnoxious. I simply have neither the time nor energy to explain everything wrong with the map alone, but just know that in multiplayer I simply default to other people to use it because it is bugged beyond hope. Otherwise a bunch of little things like vehicles randomly appearing and disappearing, characters teleporting, getting stuck and only being able to get out by suicide, falling through the world, and severe audio issues. When I am playing in multiplayer as not host I get most of Bowman's phone calls but only audio from Midas and Holt. I only ever hear Nomad when it's either a random curse or a transmission ending in "Nomad out", and I only hear Weaver only once per two hour gaming session on average. In addition there are a number of lines from Nomad that I don't get. I have compared what audio I receive and who says what with the host and I am just missing a bunch. Perhaps it has to do with playing as a female Nomad, I don't know.

Additionally, the game is slow as hell. I know everyone will talk up their PC but I have a tank for a computer and I have newer and larger games that don't take a fraction of the time to load. Other than a literal Roscosmos software this is the only thing that takes any significant amount of time to load. The person who I play with runs Windows 10 and has a much older computer, and his loading time seems to be on par with the rest of his stuff and he doesn't get many of the same bugs that I do, although he is not bug free by any means. Overall, I would guess that this game isn't well optimized for Windows 11.

Amazing game, breaks the typical Ubisoft mold too. It has a fun goofy sandbox while still being grounded enough to make Ghost Recon fans happy in 2023. Perfect balance of fun/realism and there's even a Ghost Mode for more immersive realism if you desire. Playing as a two person playthrough and having a blast. Wildlands switches from stealth to loud in a fluid way kinda like MGSV.

EAC blocks coop use on the Steam Deck though.

This is one of those games where it might be fun to play, but your time is better spent on so many other things. I played the main story from beginning to end. Got all the weapons, all the upgrades, reached max level, and I'm still playing one of the expansions. While there are some memorable missions and cool characters, at it's core, this game is more Ubisoft busywork, and the game is worse now than when it first came out (due to all the microtransactions and cosmetic loot crates in a supposedly strategic open world military game).

The good:

-Bolivia is beautiful and there's a huge amount of variation in the topography.
Gunplay is solid and fun.
-Using rebel skills is fun.
-*Certain* missions are memorable (the final battle, Bookhart, the mission with the Unidad general, and the mission with Sueno's wife to name a few). Ironically, the most fun missions for me were bonus missions completely unrelated to the story (the Predator, Sam Fisher, and the Breakpoint tie-in mission).

Cons:

-Pretty much everything in the game reminds me of another game that did a better job. Metal Gear Solid 5 has better stealth, Arma is more realistic, Hitman has more memorable missions, Far Cry has more eccentric and interesting characters. 
-The balance and the way damage is calculated is way off. Submachine guns and shotguns are just not that viable at higher difficulties. Assault rifles, LMGs, and snipers are better in 99/100 scenarios.
-Most of the special tools in the game are worthless. Lures are completely outclassed by flares, flashbangs are never more useful than frag grenades, and frag grenades themselves are outclassed by mines and C4. 


The "stupidly big but empty map full of busywork" has been done to death, I'm sick of it, and the work never really pays off. Take your money elsewhere. Also, stay away from the sequel. It's somehow even worse than this game.

The gameplay is mostly fine at the beginning, till you hit those really, really bad missions, but frankly its mostly disappointing in almost every area. Your arsenals are limited mostly to small arms, sometimes a fun vehicle, of which there are two, weee, but really leaves something to be desired. Controlling your squad and drone are highly entertaining to me personally, but they're limited to "make gun go pew" and "make thing go boom" after a short while, everything else is redundant. Noise maker? EMP? I think you mean explosion for literally everything because it has the same effect without the need to swap out in a menu (side note, the GUI in the menus is atrocious) 

A lot of gameplay is also inconsistent. Need to sneak into a military base but not allowed to be detected but also can't kill anyone? Great, I'll sneak up and press the big button that says "knock out" on a guard. Lo and behind, "knock out" is actually Bolivian slang for "Murder"and will fail you said mission. Game is also wild with how it defines "detection" in different missions, sometimes its enough for the guards to hear an explosion in the distance, sometimes you can literally have a shootout and nobody will notice. 

The story line that will make your eyes roll as soulless cardboard cuttout npcs recite 40 year old Imperialist American propaganda at you, all of which leads to you essentially filling out a shopping list with bullets. I could excuse it if the game had been made about 40 years ago but for fuck sake, there is no excuse for having this level of misunderstanding of the war on drugs at the time this was released. Not to mention, you will suffer through it all for basically nothing. Everyone dies, or everyone dies later in a different cutscene, amazing stuff.

Not to mention that its not only full of micro-transactions but you can't even directly buy what you want, its lootboxes only. And no, its not just cosmetic, there is gameplay hidden behind those boxes, like the vehicles that have actual combat use (and make the game laughably easy once you get them) 

Most people say you should buy this game when its on sale. For me personally you could not pay me to ever play a ghost recon game again (or any tom Clancy game again if the story is this bad and unaware of itself, holy fuck)

From dense forests to arid deserts, each region is meticulously designed, creating a realistic and immersive world. The attention to detail, day-night cycle, and dynamic weather contribute to the game's stunning graphics, making exploration an awe-inspiring experience.

Sound: âââââ (4/5 stars)
The sound design in Ghost Recon Wildlands is well-executed, enhancing the overall immersion of the game. The ambient sounds of the environment, gunfire, and explosions create a realistic atmosphere during missions. The voice acting for main characters is commendable, though some supporting NPCs may lack depth. The soundtrack complements the gameplay, adding to the intensity of combat and moments of suspense.

Story and Narrative: âââââ (4/5 stars)
While the premise of dismantling the Santa Blanca drug cartel sets the stage for an intriguing storyline, Ghost Recon Wildlands falls short in its narrative execution. The plot can feel somewhat predictable and fails to fully engage players emotionally. The character development lacks depth, making it difficult to form strong connections with the protagonists. Despite its potential, the story doesn't reach the same heights as previous entries in the Ghost Recon series.

Multiplayer: âââââ (4/5 stars)
The cooperative multiplayer mode is where Ghost Recon Wildlands truly shines. Joining forces with friends to tackle missions and take down targets offers a more enjoyable experience compared to playing solo. The seamless transition between single-player and multiplayer modes ensures a smooth and immersive experience. However, the absence of competitive multiplayer options might disappoint players seeking PvP gameplay.

DLCs: âââââ (3/5 stars)
Ghost Recon Wildlands' DLCs, "Narco Road" and "Fallen Ghosts," add exciting content to the game, including new missions, weapons, and storylines. "Narco Road" introduces thrilling undercover missions within the Santa Blanca cartel, focusing on daring vehicle-based gameplay. "Fallen Ghosts" ups the challenge with tougher enemy factions and intense survival gameplay. While some DLCs lack impact and suffer from occasional technical issues, overall, they enhance the game's lifespan and offer additional value to fans seeking more adventures in Bolivia.

Bugs and Updates: âââââ (3/5 stars)
Ghost Recon Wildlands had its fair share of bugs and technical issues upon release. While Ubisoft Paris addressed many of the early concerns through patches and updates, some issues persisted. The occasional AI glitches and mission bugs could disrupt the gameplay experience. However, the development team's commitment to providing updates and addressing player feedback deserves recognition.

Conclusion: 
Ghost Recon Wildlands successfully blends tactical gameplay with an expansive open-world, offering players the freedom to chart their paths in a visually stunning environment. With solid gameplay mechanics, cooperative multiplayer, and outstanding graphics, it provides hours of enjoyable gameplay. While the story could have been more compelling and certain technical issues lingered, the overall experience remains engaging and satisfying. Whether you're a fan of the series or a newcomer, Ghost Recon Wildlands is a thrilling adventure worth undertaking. if you come here after playing Breakpoint then this is a much better option.

Ghost Recon Wildlands delivers an open-world experience that combines tactical challenges and intense firefights. Set in a dramatic rendition of Bolivia, the game captures players with its breathtaking landscapes and attention to detail. 

The game's standout feature lies in its tactical gameplay mechanics. As a member of a special forces squad, you have the freedom to approach missions with a range of strategies. Whether executing a methodical infiltration and recon, coordinating synchronized takedowns with teammates, or opting for explosive assaults (that will probably end up killing you if you aren't prepared, but eh, the respawn is quick enough that it's viable with a squad of 4 players), the choice is yours. The extensive selection of weapons, gadgets, and vehicles adds depth to the tactical experience, enabling adaptability in various scenarios. Being able to swap tools on the fly and order vehicles through the resistance Just Cause style helps keep the gameplay moving since you can change play styles whenever you get bored of stealth or action.

Ghost Recon Wildlands truly shines in cooperative play, being able to join forces with up to three friends seamlessly, transitioning between single-player and cooperative sessions without any loading on the host's part. The game allows the player to plan assaults with their team before they step anywhere near the enemy and allow a greater strategic depth than similar co-op shooters like Sniper Elite or Far Cry.

While the story may not delve into deep narrative complexities and is at times very blunt, the game and its strategic cooperative gameplay make it a must-play for fans of tactical shooter. Although I like it, I cannot in good faith recommend purchasing it at the current price of $50. However, the game very regularly goes on sales to $10 and I would recommend picking it up then.

Don't play ghost mode.
Genuinely don't recommend it.
The only reason I'm doing it is because of my hyper perseverance and self-hatred.
Also, playing without teammates.

The gameplay itself is fine, fun even occasionally. Shooting feels good, but trees and bushes are wildly inconsistent with their ability to block bullets or let them through. You aren't always going to be able to tell what trees actually have collision or not until you run through them or shoot a bullet into it.
Controlling vehicles feels wonky but workable. However, it does become infuriating when you land fine on a bike going downhill and die for no reason. Vehicles get INCREDIBLY fast, and while traveling on the higher mountain-side roads, you may very well fly right off the side if you aren't careful.
The narration is incredibly meh. The characters go back and forth on medals from "hey these cartel medals are kinda cool" to "man this medal looks like shit lol", and a lot of the conversations feel incredibly xenophobic.

Ghost mode is where I say meh.
Ghost mode says it makes a realistic experience. This includes permadeath, reloading drops any ammo left in a magazine, and you are limited to 2 weapon slots (primary and secondary). 
Personally I feel that it should have just been another game difficulty, instead of a whole new mode, however I find the most annoying part to be it deleting your save. This may be a me problem, as being booted back to the main menu with a message saying "your save file ded xd" is fine the first time, but after the 2nd and 3rd time it just became aggrivating. Yes game, I realized I died and my save is gone because of that. Couldn't have guessed. This is especially aggrevating when you die in a way you feel you shouldn't have. Like a unidad patrol randomly deciding to come into this random area you're clearing out, then mainly fight you instead of the cartel also firing at them. And if you want to get rid of the unidad, you better hope you get them all in one go, or else they will pretty much constantly call in more reinforcements, leading you to HAVE to retreat or even leave the area entirely. 

Remember, I'm playing without teammates, so I only have myself to rely upon. When you play with teammates, you can get revived, have covering fire, and faces to look at so you don't go insane killing and dying. But the revive part is important. if you play without teammates in ghost mode, you die instantly if you go down. There's no skill I could see which allows you to revive yourself, nor do I know if rebels can revive you if you call them in, but this DRASTICALLY increases the difficulty of ghost mode even higher. 
Did you slightly miscalculate that fall? Well, your 8 hour run is now over :). Did you just accidentally stare at your enemies as they shot you because you didn't know you can only pull out weapons from holster with 1 2 or H? (you cannot press m1 or m2 to bring out weapons)

The last thing to gripe about is the linearity of the story and missions. You can go ANYWHERE on the map from the beginning. And if you do, you can explore a LOT of different cities and ruins and shanty towns. But you won't find ANYTHING unless you get the yummy yellow files. 
Example, there's a prisoner you can save from a chapel. However, if you come here BEFORE picking up the note that TELLS YOU there is a prisoner there for you to save, they will not spawn there.
If you find a unidad base and clear it out, loot it, then leave the area, find a yellow file that tells you there's an objective there, you will have to fight through THE ENTIRE BASE AGAIN. 

It's halfway between a yes and a no, but I'm bitter so I'm putting it at no.

I don't think i've written a review before but this game had me wanting to write one the entire time. There are pro's and con's but man do the cons just suck sometimes a little too much. Overall I'm cheap when it comes to games for fear i'll waste the money. A fear of "well what if i buy the game and don't like it" sorta situation. As of now i don't feel the game was bad, but i doubt i'll put more time into it. 


PROS
- I bought the game for 10$ so I can't really complain about the enjoyment i got out of it. I had a lot of fun trying a different FPS out. A simple youtube search for a FPS with high weapon customization (I don't like the idea of Tarkov's gameplay, and I despise battle royals honestly) and this game came up. This game is my style in some form, reminds me of far cry but in a different way.


CONS
- The AI is just ridiculous sometimes. Hiding is impossible so don't try it, just run endlessly to get away. But by far the worst part of the game and AI. Is if you ever become hunted or a threat according to the minimap that shows like your stealth status. They will always 100% know, where you're at no matter where you're hiding. Missed a shot by a couple inches from 400 yards away on a cliff side hiding in between bushes in a rock crevice. Too bad, they know exactly where your shot came from and will aggro to include shooting pinpoint mortars on you. Forcing you to relocate. Sniped someone from the same location and someone witnesses the kill, same ordeal. 
Here's a different scenario that's even more far fetched. Place a C4 somewhere and go hide or camp on the otherside of a compound. In a tower. Wherever you like, once you activate the C4 and they AI start to hunt for you, they already know your last known location at the time of being hunted. So you're hiding in the tower, aggro into hunted from an explosion, they already know you're in the tower. So you gotta relocate from there even though theres no way they even knew you were there. 
- A somewhat different con but maybe i should say each to their own. This game has a definite style that you should play to play the game so to speak. And that's stealth. I played on extreme difficulty because I wanted a tad of realism and not feel like a bullet sponge while 1 tapping other enemies. But i feel like you cant play it any other way. If you try to take them all on you'll quickly die. There were multiple times i was stealth-ing through and got caught so i attempted to fight my way to a win. But died every time i think. There was even a case that a pinged enemy was running towards me, i knew i had the advantage because i would see him coming before turning the corner. And In a magical buggy way, he turned the corner. appeared further than where he stopped,and shot me instantly before i could possible even think about shooting back. And I knew he was coming! 
- I think lastly, driving controls are atrocious. I'm mouse and keyboard and i understand the issue that a keyboard is not analog input. But man everything sucks. Even if you just baby tap cars it still wants to fling left and right. You can adjust the camera so you cant hardly see anything. You have to constantly adjust the camera with your mouse instead. Flying controls are equally bad. The helicopter has an updated new controls that are easier for sure than what the classic controls. But still, with the mouse controls it feels impossible to control the gun. Yes you can adjust the sensitivity but it felt useless. Even on low sensitivity the helicopter would swing past further than where intended. Crank up the mouse sensitivity. And it's the same problem, just faster. 

Overall, do i recommend the game? Yes, I cant say I'm upset or anything. Whenever the cons would come up I would just think about them every time, and would just put it in the back of my mind, its the wildpoint gameplay. I would just do things differently if i had the choice to change things in game.

The gameplay is great. Lots of guns and vehicles to mess around with, they gunplay is pretty good, driving is serviceable, AI squadmates are helpful and you can turn them off if you want to go solo, ordering your squad to start assault from a vehicle is really fun, and the story is pretty good from what I've seen... BUT the open world gameplay is terrible. The design itself is pretty good as it feels lively and each region feels different. However, the open world suffers from the same problem that AC: Odyssey has: Despite having unique regions, it's too big for its own good and you'll be spending a good chunk of your playtime just traversing the map to get important collectables for unlocks and upgrades.

If you can get past the terrible open world gameplay, I definitely recommend this game. 
If you have a limited amount of time per game session, stay away as you'll be wasting a lot of it just traversing the map.

Ghost Recon Wildlands is an outstanding tactical shooter that delivers an immersive open-world experience. From the moment I started playing, I was hooked on its gripping storyline, vast landscapes, and thrilling gameplay. As a fan of the Ghost Recon franchise, Wildlands exceeded my expectations and solidified its place as one of the best games in the series.

The first thing that struck me was the game's breathtaking open-world environment. The fictionalized version of Bolivia is stunningly realized, with diverse landscapes ranging from dense jungles and towering mountains to sprawling salt flats and bustling cities. The attention to detail is exceptional, and the sheer scale of the world is awe-inspiring.

The gameplay mechanics are polished and offer players a wide range of options to tackle missions and objectives. The freedom of choice is one of the game's strongest aspects. You can approach missions stealthily, gathering intel and taking down enemies covertly, or go in guns blazing, causing chaos and explosions. The variety of weapons, equipment, and vehicles at your disposal is extensive, allowing for strategic planning and execution.

One of the highlights of Ghost Recon Wildlands is the seamless co-op experience. Playing with friends or joining a team online adds a new layer of excitement to the game. Coordinating tactics, executing synchronized takedowns, and working together to accomplish missions is incredibly satisfying. The teamwork required brings out the best of the tactical gameplay that the series is known for.

The story campaign is engaging and keeps you invested throughout your journey. Taking down the vicious drug cartel, Santa Blanca, feels like a monumental task, and each mission contributes to the overarching narrative. The game's writing and voice acting are top-notch, immersing you in a gritty world filled with interesting characters and high-stakes situations.

Moreover, the developers have consistently supported Ghost Recon Wildlands with updates, patches, and new content, ensuring a rich and evolving experience for players. The addition of the Ghost War PvP mode further extends the game's longevity, offering intense multiplayer matches that put your skills to the test against other players.

Lastly, the technical performance on Steam is excellent. The game runs smoothly, and the graphics are visually stunning, showcasing the beauty of the environment and the detailed character models.

In conclusion, Ghost Recon Wildlands is a masterpiece of tactical open-world gaming. With its captivating storyline, vast and immersive world, engaging gameplay, and robust co-op experience, it stands as a shining example of what a tactical shooter can achieve. If you're a fan of the genre or simply looking for an unforgettable gaming experience, I wholeheartedly recommend Ghost Recon Wildlands on Steam.

I just wasted a chunk of my precious life playing Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands, and let me tell ya, it's as exciting as watching paint dry. This game claims to be all about tactical warfare, but it feels more like a snooze-fest on steroids.

First things first, the storyline is about as captivating as a limp lettuce leaf. I mean, seriously, who came up with this generic, cookie-cutter plot? It's like they threw in every clichÃ© they could find and hoped for the best. Yawn.

And don't even get me started on the characters. They're about as memorable as that guy you met once at a party and forgot about immediately. The voice acting is so cringe-worthy that it made me want to stab my eardrums with a rusty spoon. Bravo, developers!

Now, let's talk about the gameplay. Sure, you can roam around this vast open world, but what's the point? The missions are repetitive as hell, and the AI is dumber than a bag of rocks. I've seen more intelligent behavior from a pigeon. It's like the developers took "tactical" and replaced it with "tacti-dull."

Oh, and the graphics? Mediocre at best. The environment looks like it was designed by an intern with a limited budget and a bad taste in colors. There's no wow factor here, folks. Just a whole lot of meh.

But hey, if you're into mind-numbingly dull gameplay, a forgettable story, and characters that you couldn't care less about, then go ahead and waste your hard-earned cash on this snooze fest. Personally, I'd rather watch paint dry or count the tiles on my bathroom floor. At least that would be more entertaining than Ghost Recon Wildlands.

However the game defiantly suffers a few problems, The biggest problem is Unidad, they might be the most annoying enemy's I have ever played against in a video game, they kill you so quickly. they have a massive amount of health, AND the infinity respawn until you escape them, it goes from challenging to tedious very quickly. And holy shit there are a couple of dogshit missions in this game. One of them you have to sneak into a Unidad base (shockingly the terrible mission has Unidad in it) and kill some guy. However it is literally impossible to normally sneak into the base because there are rebels fighting Unidad at every entrance, it was a clusterfuck to complete. But fuck me it wasn't the worst mission. The mission where you help Sam Fisher. Shockingly again you have to sneak into an Unidad base, this time without killing anyone, which is already really fucking annoying. But then you have to defend Sam (who is supposed to be an incredibly skilled soldier) whilst he hacks a fucking laptop for 5 mins. But here's the very fun part, Unidad soldiers infinity spawn right fucking on top of you constantly, including fucking attack helicopters which will insta-kill you if you are hit by it's rockets, all while the super soldier Sam Fisher sits there with his dick in his hand hacking a fucking laptop. It is 100% the most annoying mission I have ever played in a video game and I didn't complete it, hell I barley even made it to the 2 min mark. But aside from Unidad and a few missions (please don't do the Sam Fisher mission) the game is overall very fun. The side missions get repetitive pretty quickly so I just didn't do any of them, and the story was fine. Even though the game has a few of the worst missions in gaming history (which you technically don't even have to do) I'd still say it was very fun. However not fun enough to make me want to play Breakpoint.

Before I get into my review, I would like to start off by saying that I would buy Ghost Recon Wildlands over Breakpoint.

Starting off, Wildlands offers you to be able to do missions whenever you want, in whichever order you'd like. There is a lot to discover and it is fairly easy to find new weapons, attachments or skill points. This all through a beautiful landscape and map.

Next, customization in this game is fairly nice, since there is a lot of clothes, accessories and whatever else to choose from, so you can easily adjust your character to whichever environment that you'd like.

Lastly, the game allows you to have three friends to play along with you, though same goes for Breakpoint as well, this really allows you to communicate and plan tactics with your friends. Talking about tactics, stealth in both Wildlands and Breakpoint are both a nice way to get through the game.

To summarize my review, I am quite happy about my purchase. Though I really recommend you play this game with your friends.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

A solid game with 4 player coop. Has a massive map, a lot of content with a bit of variation but you end up doing the same things over and over. Tier One mode unlocks after you level up and gives supplies bonuses but forces you to play on the hardest difficulty.

Unfortunately the game suffers from a lot of Quality of Life (QOL) issues. You will spend most of your time down waiting for a revive, or repeating missions over and over because the target died or someone got detected. You will be stuck staring at a loading screen every time you die, fail a mission, or fast travel. Even with an NVMe SSD the load times are long. You can shoot while riding as a passenger on cars and helicopters but it is very difficult to aim as your aim moves with the vehicle. Vehicles also have low health and don't last long, even the APC. Calling for a vehicle delivery will often spawn it far from the group in dumb places which is infuriating as you will be using it all the time.

This is one of those games like GTA 5 which is overall a fun game but very frustrating at the same time due to all the issues. With server problems it's hard to play in coop which is what this game was built for. Hard to recommend unless it's 10 dollars and there's nothing better to play.

You can have several main quests available at once. Say one of these requires you to do a task without raising an alarm. 
Say now you are in a rare armed helicpoter, and you find an enemy convoy that has some resources you would like. So you attack the convoy. The convoy tries to escape, and by chance drives right next to the main quest. The action from the convoy triggeres the alarm, and giving you a mission failed.

Gameplay and Tactical Depth:
Wildlands excels in providing players with a deep and tactical gameplay experience. As a member of an elite Ghost Recon team, players are tasked with dismantling the Santa Blanca drug cartel. The game offers a wide range of tactical options, including stealth, long-range sniping, and coordinated team assaults, allowing players to approach missions in their preferred playstyle.

The open-world nature of Wildlands adds a layer of freedom and exploration rarely seen in tactical shooters. Players can navigate the massive and diverse Bolivian landscape on foot, by vehicle, or even by air, uncovering hidden objectives, gathering intel, and engaging in dynamic encounters. The game's attention to detail, including realistic ballistics, weapon customization, and equipment choices, further enhances the tactical depth and authenticity of the gameplay.

Cooperative Multiplayer:
Wildlands shines when played cooperatively with friends. The game supports seamless drop-in, drop-out multiplayer, allowing players to collaborate and tackle missions together. The cooperative gameplay mechanics, such as synchronized takedowns and coordinated squad maneuvers, make for thrilling and rewarding teamwork experiences. Whether it's infiltrating enemy compounds, coordinating synchronized shots, or executing complex strategies, Wildlands offers a dynamic and engaging cooperative multiplayer mode that greatly enhances the game's replayability and enjoyment.

Open-World Environment:
The expansive and detailed open-world environment of Wildlands is a standout feature. The Bolivian landscape is breathtakingly recreated, featuring a diverse range of biomes, from dense jungles to arid deserts and snowy mountains. The world feels alive, with civilian and cartel activities occurring dynamically, providing opportunities for emergent gameplay moments. The attention to detail in the environment design, combined with the day-night cycle, dynamic weather, and realistic lighting, adds to the immersion and authenticity of the game world.

Narrative and Character Development:
While Wildlands' narrative may not be the main focus, it successfully sets the stage for the player's mission in Bolivia. The game's story unfolds through mission briefings, cutscenes, and character interactions. While the plot may not offer groundbreaking storytelling, the character development within the Ghost Recon team adds depth and emotional investment to the experience. Each member of the team has a distinct personality and backstory, creating a sense of camaraderie and attachment as players progress through the game.

Visuals and Audio:
Wildlands boasts impressive visuals, with stunning landscapes, detailed character models, and realistic animations. The game's attention to environmental details, such as flora and fauna, further adds to the immersion. The audio design, including weapon sounds, environmental ambiance, and voice acting, is top-notch and contributes to the overall realism and atmosphere of the game.

Conclusion:
Tom Clancy's Ghost ReconÂ® Wildlands offers a compelling and immersive tactical adventure set in a vast open-world environment. With its deep tactical gameplay, cooperative multiplayer, and attention to detail, the game provides an engaging experience for fans of the tactical shooter genre. While the narrative may not be the game's strongest aspect, the expansive world, realistic mechanics, and cooperative play make Wildlands a standout entry in the Ghost Recon series.

Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands is an action-packed, tactical shooter game that takes players on an adrenaline-fueled journey through the stunning and expansive open world of Bolivia. Developed by Ubisoft Paris and released in 2017, it offers an immersive experience filled with intense firefights, stealth missions, and breathtaking landscapes. As a fan of the Ghost Recon series, I found this installment to be a compelling addition to the franchise, although not without a few minor drawbacks.

One of the standout features of Ghost Recon Wildlands is its massive open world. Bolivia is beautifully rendered, offering diverse environments ranging from lush jungles to arid deserts, towering mountains to sprawling urban areas. The attention to detail is commendable, creating an atmosphere that feels alive and authentic. Exploring the vast landscape, players can choose to tackle missions in any order they please, providing a sense of freedom and agency rarely seen in similar games.

The gameplay in Wildlands strikes a perfect balance between tactical strategy and exhilarating combat. Players assume the role of a member of the elite Ghost Recon team, tasked with taking down a powerful drug cartel. Whether playing solo or in cooperative multiplayer with friends, the game offers a wide array of tools, weapons, and vehicles to accomplish missions in your own style. The tactical aspect is enhanced by the ability to mark enemies, coordinate synchronized shots with teammates, and execute carefully planned infiltration strategies.

In terms of visuals and audio design, Ghost Recon Wildlands delivers a high-quality experience. The attention to detail in the character models, weapon animations, and environmental effects is impressive. The sound design effectively captures the chaos of combat, and the dynamic day-night cycle and weather system contribute to the immersion. However, occasional visual glitches and repetitive character animations can momentarily detract from an otherwise polished presentation.

While the game's strengths lie in its cooperative multiplayer experience, the single-player campaign offers a solid and enjoyable experience as well. The AI teammates are competent and can be given simple commands, making solo play a viable option. However, their behavior can be predictable at times, and a deeper level of squad customization would have been a welcome addition.

One area where Ghost Recon Wildlands falls short is the narrative. Although the premise of taking down a drug cartel is intriguing, the story lacks depth and fails to develop memorable characters or a compelling plot. The game's focus is more on the gameplay and exploration, but a stronger narrative would have added an extra layer of immersion and motivation.

In conclusion, Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands offers an exhilarating and vast open-world experience that fans of tactical shooters will thoroughly enjoy. The game's attention to detail, engaging gameplay mechanics, and cooperative multiplayer elements make it a standout title in the genre. Ghost Recon Wildlands is an action-packed tactical shooter that takes players on an adrenaline-fueled journey through the stunning landscapes of Bolivia. With its expansive open-world setting, diverse mission structure, and intense cooperative gameplay, Wildlands offers an immersive experience that is both exhilarating and satisfying.

One of the standout features of Ghost Recon Wildlands is its vast and visually stunning open-world environment. From dense jungles to arid deserts, the game's recreation of Bolivia is breathtakingly detailed. The varied terrain provides players with a multitude of strategic options, allowing for diverse approaches to each mission. Whether you choose to engage enemies from a distance with a sniper rifle or engage in close-quarters combat, the game offers a great deal of freedom in how you tackle each objective.

The gameplay mechanics in Wildlands are well-crafted, providing a satisfying blend of tactical planning and intense action. As the leader of an elite Special Forces team, you are tasked with taking down a powerful drug cartel. The game encourages players to carefully plan their missions, coordinating with teammates and utilizing a wide array of weapons, gadgets, and vehicles. The cooperative aspect is particularly impressive, as playing with friends adds a whole new layer of excitement and strategic possibilities.

In terms of mission variety, Ghost Recon Wildlands shines. Each mission feels distinct and presents its own set of challenges. Whether you're infiltrating enemy bases, rescuing hostages, or gathering intel, there is always a sense of urgency and tension. The dynamic nature of the game world further enhances the replayability, as enemy patrols and encounters can vary in each playthrough, ensuring that no mission feels exactly the same.

The game's narrative, while not groundbreaking, provides a solid backdrop for the action-packed gameplay. The story follows a team of Ghosts as they dismantle the Santa Blanca cartel and disrupt their operations. While the characters themselves are not particularly deep, their interactions and dialogue add a layer of camaraderie and personality to the game.

While Ghost Recon Wildlands offers an exceptional gameplay experience, it does have a few minor flaws. The AI of both friendly and enemy NPCs can occasionally be inconsistent, leading to moments of frustration or immersion-breaking situations. Additionally, some players might find the game's vast open world to be overwhelming, as the sheer size of the map can make navigation a bit cumbersome at times.

Overall, Ghost Recon Wildlands is an outstanding tactical shooter that delivers an exciting and immersive experience. With its stunning open world, engaging cooperative gameplay, and diverse mission structure, the game offers hours of thrilling entertainment for fans of the genre. Despite a few minor flaws, Wildlands succeeds in delivering a highly enjoyable experience that is well worth diving into.

[code]Ghost Recon Wildlands offers a lot of open world content for fans of tactical shooters and is especially enjoyable as a coop game, however, it also gets repetitive very quickly and suffers from occasional technical problems[/code]

The best way to describe [i]Wildlands[/i] is probably this: Itâs a typical modern Ubisoft game, with all the strengths and weaknesses that come attached with that. On the one hand, [i]Wildlands[/i] offers a vast open world with different environments, ranging from forests to deserts to mountains. Said open world, Bolivia in this case, is also filled to the brim with content, from story missions to side activities, which are cramming up your in-game map. And of course, there are lots and lots of ways to upgrade your character: level ups, skill trees, new weapons (& weapon parts for an in-game gunsmith) to find, rebel support upgrades, etc. â in short, [i]Wildlands[/i] gives you a lot of different opportunities to invest your time.

On the other hand, the sheer mass of content also means that the developers favor quantity over the quality of the individual activities. Many of the upgrades donât really matter â a gun I received earl in the game was better than any other gun I found throughout the rest of it. The novelty of infiltrating bases, killing high value targets or escorting them quickly wears off once you discover that [i]Wildlands[/i] basically reuses the same few mission structures throughout the entire game. And considering that even though the environments look different, many of the bases, camps and hideouts do not, all of your infiltrations or shootouts will quickly turn into a blur. Even though I spent 54h in the game to tackle all of the available story missions, I wonât be able to name even one location that stood out to me â in fact, the many, many locations you visit are so generic that I wouldnât be able to draw you a map of even one of them.

That said, especially in coop, the basic gameplay loop works solid enough that the generic locations wonât matter much at first. Itâs fun to use the variety of gadgets & approaches [i]Wildlands[/i] offers in order to accomplish objectives just the way you want. You could use a helicopter and a parachute to drop into an enemy base, barge in with a tank or sneak your way in by stealthily eliminating guards in your way. Especially the missions tasking you with killing a specific target allow for different tactics â sometimes a well-timed sniper shot from a nearby mountain is all it takes, sometimes a full-on assault with allied rebel NPCs might be a better choice.

[i]Wildlands[/i] offers two enemy factions, the Santa Blanca cartel and Unidad, which sort of work like the police in the [i]Grand Theft Auto[/i] franchise. Both factions got normal goons with guns as well as special types (snipers, armored enemies). Sometimes youâll also encounter enemy vehicles, like helicopters or tanks. However, as the enemy variety is pretty low and vehicles are only used in certain cases (e.g. enemy convoys), theyâre rarely more than simple gunfodder. If you want to infiltrate a base you might want to take of snipers first, but you wonât have to change your approach because of certain enemy types - disappointing. It would have been nice to make plans based on the enemies present, not just on the location alone.

Speaking about the variety in approaching objectives I previously praised, I also have to point it that this sadly doesnât last forever. Especially on higher difficulty (or the âTier Oneâ-mode available after reaching max level), [i]Wildlands[/i] becomes a much different game. Enemies can kill you almost immediately now and their locations arenât hinted at on the map anymore, which basically makes stealth approaches the only viable option if you want to complete missions. Considering [i]Wildlands[/i] is a tactical shooter after all, this isnât surprising, but Iâm still mentioning it for those who donât want to sneak around guards all the time.

My biggest gripe with the stealth approaches in [i]Wildlands[/i] concerns the enemy AI, which can ruin your well-planned approaches to a mission in more ways than you expect. Throughout most of the game, the AI is solid enough: enemies arenât particularly smart, but they do take cover when shoot at from afar and call for help if needed. What makes them so annoying in terms of stealth approaches, however, is their unpredictable spotting. Sometimes enemies are able to spot you through walls or other solid structures (the snipers in particular), sometimes they donât react to corpses of their friends but at other times they immediately sound the alarm instead. Theyâre also very good at âcoincidentallyâ heading directly to your location when searching for you: One time I had an entire truck of reinforcements spawn directly behind me even though it was only my coop partner they spotted. These AI issues can make stealth approaches quite frustrating, especially as mission checkpoints can be quite bad as well.

Anyway, even while stealth doesnât work as well as it should be, getting spotted is less frustrating when you got a coop partner to help you out: [i]Wildlands[/i] opens up a lot more if you got friends to play with. Especially on lower difficulty, you can simply go wild while approaching missions, which is a lot of fun. Maybe one of you is piloting a helicopter transporting another, who is using a sniper to take out a target from above. Or youâre participating in a great car chase, with one player driving while the other is trying to take down your pursuers. But even on higher difficulties itâs really entertaining to infiltrate a base with each player taking care of a different corner and I canât think of many games allowing for all these moments at once.

That said, while the generic locations and missions as well as the general repetitiveness of [i]Wildlands[/i] donât feel as bad if you play this game in coop and I highly recommend playing this game with friends, coop also comes with additional problems. These are mainly of the technical sort, like progress sometimes not being properly saved when finishing missions together. Especially the âSilent Spadeâ mission was bugged, with me receiving the rewards for finishing the mission together while my coop partner was stuck at an earlier checkpoint according to the game. Additionally, while the game ran fine once connected, we encountered many issues trying to join each otherâs lobby. This might be thanks to Ubisoft Connect, which is required if you want to play this game â online or not.

Lastly, letâs talk about the story of [i]Wildlands[/i]. The basic set-up of [i]Wildlands[/i] is basically to take down a big bad cartel boss, however, in order to approach him you have to take down a dozen of his underlings first. Of course, it shouldnât be surprising that the story of [i]Wildlands[/i] is quite cliched and doesnât feel very coherent, as you can tackle the story missions in any order you want. Considering you also donât encounter the big bad until the final mission, apart from a handful of previous voice lines, the big villain doesnât receive much characterization beyond âheâs evilâ. Frankly, the entire story set-up feels like itâs just window-dressing for the open world activities anyway, so donât expect it to be more than that.

Concluding, [i]Wildlands[/i] does offer a solid gameplay loop thatâs especially great when experienced with friends. But it also suffers from a problem of quantity over quality, which might lead to a few fun hours at first but a feeling of boredom later on. The longer you play, the more you realize that [i]Wildlands[/i] is lacking depth and some true variety. Itâs fun but for a tactical shooter, it's also a bit mindless and might be best experienced with some long breaks between sessions.

Revised: Yes it does have flaws and the repetition is best avoided by skipping the side missions and the endless collecting. 

What it does have going for it is the beautiful environment, careful detail of characters, props, weapons, and so on. You can't fault Ubisoft for skimping on the artwork for its titles. Likewise, the map is large and the game allows you to explore it however you choose; there is no set path, but obviously the harder opponents will likely need better gear to beat than what you start out with. 

The main criticism I have is that the AI of the enemies is poor. They have the amazing capability of pinpointing your location (and relaying this information to all of their mates) perfectly should you get caught out. The AI doesn't seem to notice that their friends are missing unless they discover the body, but only within a critical time because the bodies are rapidly claimed by the earth soon after death. Moreover, like Far Cry 2, areas you clear are repopulated by the same band of cretins you killed earlier, but there's no indication why this happens. Did I fail to clear it properly?

Your own team is hindered by poor AI and a number of contrivances to seemingly work around the AI limitations. For a while I waited patiently while my three teammates carefully lined themselves up, opened vehicle doors and sat down. Then I realised that it doesn't matter if you just drive off because they magically teleport into the vehicle anyway. 

There are loads of weapons, but it's a confusing mess of restricted choice. You'd think that unlocking (via a pick-up on the map) an attachment for assault rifles would work on all assault rifles, but this is not the case. Some require purchasing from the Ubisoft store or trudging around additional locations on the map. 

Speaking of weapons, the design of the game seems to imply that sniping beyond 500 metres is off limits. The game world doesn't seem to render beyond a certain distance and luckily so, because the gravity in this game is pretty strong. So strong in fact that shots over 200 metres require a lot of compensation to connect. And you do want them to connect because alerting the enemies to your presence means the magic pinpointing of your location to everyone all the time.

I gave up after completing the first area. Too many annoyances and too much trudging around for widgets. It all felt very familiar in the Ubisoft tradition of recycling ideas and assets into new games. I felt like I had played bits of Wildlands before in Far Cry 3 and I'm sure the voice actors sounded familiar. 

In short, if you've played any Ubisoft open world game in recent years you've basically played this one already. I'm just glad I bought it in the sale.
