Gameplay:
+ good gunplay
+ lots of gun and character customization and personalization
+ massive, diverse map
- distance between everything makes travel often tedious
- the grind is real - this game takes a _while_, even if you don't plan to 100% this game
- a few random missions are weirdly hard/unforgiving
+ civilians (and strict orders to not attack them) keeps gunplay interesting and careful, prevents turning the game into a shoot 'em up

Graphics/Sound:
+ gorgeous world
+ smooth, natural character animations
- this PC port doesn't feel too optimized. Even on a desktop RTX 3-series, I changed to lower settings and still had occasional stutter.
- some long load times (especially with Internet on - see my note at the end)
+ gun customization sounds are oh so satisfying
+ voices and ambient sounds enhance gameplay

Story:
+ good characterizations of enemies
- ...the protagonist, not so much
+ refreshing seeing "playing the long game" in stories, where results come with time
- in my personal experience, I felt little investment in cutscenes and individual characters
+ some fun cameos from the "Ubisoft cinematic universe"

Overall: great third-person RPG shooter that requires a lot of grind. If you have the time (and can figure out how to play with a friend), it's worth it.

Other notes:
- I only played offline - no friends connected, no co-op. I heard some had issues with it. Even then, the Internet connection makes load times longer. I just put the Ubisoft launcher in offline mode, that fixed it.
- this review is from someone who's only other Ghost Recon game played is "Advanced Warfighter 2" on the Xbox 360 (solid game btw). So I can't really rate it on whether it lives up to the rest of the series or not.
- high profanity warning - both in cutscenes and gameplay, your character swears often when things go wrong. The most you can do is mute _all_ voices, including cutscenes, enemies, other characters, etc. So if you are unsure about profanity, it's either all or nothing.

The game offers an extensive and immersive experience, allowing players to explore the vast open-world environment while engaging in thrilling tactical combat.

The game's story is engaging and well-crafted, with a variety of missions and objectives that keep you on your toes. The main campaign is divided into multiple regions, each with its own unique terrain, culture, and storylines. The game also features side missions, which offer additional challenges and rewards.

What sets Ghost ReconÂ® Wildlands apart from other games is its emphasis on tactical gameplay. You can choose to take on each mission with a different approach, whether it's through stealth, sniping, or full-on assault. The game rewards players who take a more strategic approach, using gadgets, drones, and teamwork to take down enemies. The game's graphics are impressive, with a realistic depiction of the Bolivian landscape, including mountains, forests, and deserts. The attention to detail is also evident in the character models, weapons, and vehicles, which are all rendered with a high degree of realism.

One of the standout features of Ghost ReconÂ® Wildlands is the cooperative multiplayer mode, which allows up to four players to play together in the open-world environment. This adds a new level of teamwork and strategy to the game, as players can coordinate their tactics and take on the drug cartel as a cohesive unit. While the game does have some minor flaws, such as occasional glitches and AI issues, these do not detract from the overall experience. In conclusion, Tom Clancy's Ghost ReconÂ® Wildlands is a well-designed and immersive tactical shooter that offers hours of engaging gameplay, with its tactical combat, open-world exploration, and cooperative multiplayer mode, making it a must-play for fans of the genre.

Great tactical stealth shooter. At higher difficulties (Advanced and Extreme) enemies react believably, take cover, flank you, call for backup, investigate noises etc. You are also not a bullet sponge and will not last long under sustained fire. To succeed you need to plan ahead, recon the area thoroughly with the drone, watch patrol routes, take out lone enemies first so as not to attract attention. You have a lot of freedom to approach missions in the way you want thanks to the many vehicles you can drive or pilot and the vast open world. It's true that side missions lack variety - there are a set range of side missions and they are essentially repeated with minor variations in each province. However, the main story missions I found to be very compelling and varied, and the moment-to-moment stealth gameplay is addictive and satisfying. The storyline is predictable and cookie-cutter, with highly questionable ethics, but if you can disconnect that part of your brain and focus on the high quality tactical combat in a beautiful open world you will definitely have a blast with this.

Updated review: Good game marred by crappy software by Ubisoft. On the Steam Deck, it slows down then crashes after a few minutes because of the Ubisoft Connect Overlay. This can be fixed by a few tweaks to make it run smoothly:

1. Switch to Desktop Mode.
2. Launch the game once then quit.
3. On the taskbar, click the Ubisoft Connect icon.
4. Go to Settings.
5. Uncheck Enable Ubisoft Connect Overlay.
6. Launch the game.

Story: it is somewhat interesting. Not brilliant, but serves it's purpose and can have some twists sometimes. You are a part of special group called Ghosts. As an overall package, I really liked it, but it can start to be boring after half of the game, just because the gameplay formula does not change at all :)
World: this is the best thing in the game, because you have basically everything here. Jungles, deserts, snow, moderate climate, mountains, swamps. It is beautiful!
I'd say it is 6-7/10 depeniding on things you like.

A problem i have with this game: No manual save function; it just auto-saves at certain mission points. 

All in all worth to get, when on sale. No regrets here.

Subjective pro points:
- Gameplay: Ghost Mode (a must for me, everything else much too easy); it needs then manual save backups* outside the game.
- Protagonist start: Plenty options (male, female, etc.).
- Settings: Very very plenty available (FX, HUD).
- Story, the world and overall: Alright.
- Bugs, technical: Personally haven't experienced them, except: In Character Creation window, you cannot go back into menu, you are forced to create a character and save it.
- Ubisoft Connect offline play.

Subjective contra points:
- Start equipment options: Much too much.
- Progression (protagonist): Way too easy.
- Loot: Feels like always the same, should be much more rare and random.
- Side missions: When not successful, they spawn back in the same manner, just too easy to make those objectives sooner or later. A failure should be a failure.
- Locations: When cleaned one of enemies, they spawn back. In this matter, no progression. Immersion bummer. They should be kept quasi liberated.
- Challenge: With the former points in mind, a feeling like "finally, we got it" is very very seldom. 
- Permadeath in Ghost Mode: There should be an option to enable/disable the feature in this Mode.
- Ubisoft Connect.

* recently i wasn't able to restart a save backup, for whatever reason the game does not consider the save backup, although formerly it worked that way. This is very annoying and stops me possibly to play on.

Subjective resumed judgement, gameplay etc.: This game has or could have more potential. Fe. Needs, like fatigue/breaks/sleep and of course food (drinks and edibles). Then it would or could be a shooter masterpiece with RPG elements. As it is now, it won't keep me playing for longer.

Single player review only. 

I havent played military shooters in a while, got burned out during the 360/PS3 days. But i was looking for another open world game, killing dudes, upgrading, finding the things etc. Since this game was 80% off i figured why not. And this game delivers. There actually may be *too* many things to do in this game. I spent a good portion just doing side missions, exploring and doing some of the main quests. But then it started to feel too repetitive but in a negative way. Not sure why. Thankfully though, the main story missions are pretty damn good, same with the voice work. 

As a fan of Far Cry, i wanted more of that feel here. So i played in Arcade (easy) difficulty, which isnt exactly easy but is way more forgiving. However, if you want the full tactical experience you can ramp up the difficulty and turn off the hud, waypoints, and more if you wish. You can play with an AI squad which is what i did, but you can also remove them completely and go solo which i thought was a nice feature. But there's some big downsides to that too. You cant get revived, and you lose the ability to have your squad mark targets and kill them instantly with a perk called sync shot in which they do it silently and is very helpful and fun because they do it silently. 

Anyways, i had only about 3 or 4 generals(?) to kill before killing the main bad guy. I decided to wrap things up and beat the final boss and got what i suppose is the "bad" ending, but i thought it was pretty good. Then in typical open world fashion you get booted back to the game to continue on if you wish with a notification that i beat 80% of the bosses and if i do them all i'll get a different ending. So I figured why not and spent a few more hours killing all of them and then the main bad guy. The ending was different, but tbh i kinda liked the other one better. Alternatively, if you do things a certain way you can actually kill the main bad guy pretty early on if you want as well, although all the cutscenes afterward will still go on as though he never died which sorta ruins consistency, so dont do that. 

Theres tons and tons of weapons, parts and things to find. The weapon parts annoyed me the most though because a weapon part is only good for ONE specific weapon instead of its class. So you can go on for dozens and dozens of hours collecting parts for weapons you either dont want to use or for a weapon you dont even have. Plus, you can only carry two weapons and your side pistol. No upgrades for an extra weapon slot or two which was a bummer. I got to the point where i found a good assualt rifle and sniper rifle both with suppressors and i was doing just fine with them and never bothered with looking for all the other crap out there. 

Upgrades are good, but i wish there were more, especially considering theres SO much you can do in this game. It got to the point where i upgraded everything i wanted to and didnt care much to upgrade anything else.  Side missions will reward you with one of four types of resources that you need to upgrade a certain skill. Since i upgraded what i want enough i stopped doing side missions and banked over 65 skill points which i couldnt use at all. It would have been nice to use them for something extra like a 1% bonus to something like in the AC Origins/Odyssey games.

Overall though it was a decent shooter.

Let's get the bad out of the way:
- Game came out in 2017, in 2023 still having server issues.
- Occasional crashes caused by unoptimized performance, surprisingly taxing even on RTX 3080 hardware.

Ok, now to the meat of the game:

This is one of those rare games where I can and have to wholeheartedly recommend that you play co-op either with strangers, or better yet, with friends. Why?

If you play alone, it's standard Ubisoft open-world fare: massive areas, paper-thin exploration, outposts to clear, loot to collect and forget about yada-yada...There are interesting repeatable tasks such as convoy ambush, rebel support, and multiple approaches you can take to complete them, which is very neat. Most of the items in game you can earn by completing missions, doing challenges, so no real money required - which is very strange for Ubisoft.

HOWEVER, with friends, that's where the game truly shines: tactical mishaps, failure of coordination, helicopter crashes, accidental killings of VIPs...Wait, you might be asking: why is this guy listing stupid stuff that you generally would hate in a co-op environment? Trust me: failures are fun, because with a team of functional primates, you will learn - get better - and once you and your teammates get the hold of things, it gets really, and I mean REALLY badass. Like movie-level badass.

But uh, servers still suck though.

It's nothing outstanding, but for being a fairly typical Ubisoft open-world game it's all right. The enemy characters get decent characterization from the cutscene videos & collectible audio logs, text, and trinkets. The gunplay is OK but the enemies are silly, being perfect shots with x-ray vision once you're considered "spotted" (no matter who spotted you or how long ago), but completely oblivious to a stealthed player picking them off. Still, it is fun to ride around in helicopters, scout out a place by drone, and then blow everything up. It's not the most heavily-optimized game and doesn't have modern features like HDR or RTX but it does look pretty good and runs OK (and there's plenty of settings to fiddle with, including the required FOV slider).

I do wish the cutscene videos didn't have the obnoxious "zoomed in way too close at an oblique angle" style that just makes the details hard to see and a bit nauseating. I know it's not really the Ghost Recon thing, but I also kinda wish they'd taken the angle of showing the real-world influences for this fictional game, like cocaine production in Bolivia (it is a thing), worship of Santa Muerte (this is a real religious movement), or the origins of some of the characters (like El Pozolero, who at least in modus operandi is based on an actual Sinaloa cartel killer); it is fascinating to look into the details, but you'll have to dig through the wiki and search for info yourself.

I haven't beaten it yet but I'm about halfway through full completion and it's a fun ride. My kid likes to watch me play and enjoys the fact that we can customize the character's appearance, though I wish there was a no-profanity option for when she's sitting with me.

Follows the Ubisoft playbook to near perfection. Open world, campaign, side missions for additional resources and weapons, plenty of said weapons, vehicles to use... even high end supercars, customazible gear and weapons, even reasonably useful AI squad members if you're flying solo or short handed.

It's fun and that's what games are for.

BACK STORY:
To be honest, I used to hate Ghost Recon. When it was first announced in 2015, it just didn't appeal to me, and I kept confusing it with other Tom Clancy games like Rainbow Six Siege and The Division, trust me it was the Tom Clancy name, lol. I know it sounds embarrassing, but I just couldn't get excited about it. At the time, everything was turning into an open-world game, and Ghost Recon just didn't seem to fit that mold. 

 Around the time Rainbow Six Siege was releasing, I found myself coming up with numerous excuses as to why I wouldn't get the game. I would purposely confuse the game with Ghost Recon, a completely different game. My friends would attempt to correct me, but I stubbornly clung to my delusions. I vividly recall saying things like, "Rainbow Six Siege is an open-world shooter, I'm not interested in that kind of game." To which my friends would say, "No, that's Ghost Recon! You should really give Siege a chance, it's going to be so much fun, just buy the game."I was too insecure to admit that I didn't have a next-gen console and was only debating with them to hide that fact

I would eventually get a PS4 in 2017. In the years that followed, Ubisoft would drop banger after banger. From Far Cry 5 to Assassin's Creed Odyssey, and even made a comeback with games like Siege and For Honor, The amount of hours I spent playing those games was insane, with Odessey being the peak of my enjoyment. I would eventually platinum it and move on. 
That's when my friend would recommend Ghost Recon Wildlands as our next playthrough. I really treasured our friendship but I was opposed to the idea. After some thought, I agreed, because this was the same friend who game-shared me Odessey, and man, did I love that game. So in return, I bought the game and game-shared him. We would play it but never really got into it, going as far as the end of the tutorial mission. Our lives would move on, with him and work and me and school. Unfortunately, our friendship would eventually fade when Covid hit the globe. 

Fast forward to 2021, and I'm a workaholic who plays Rainbow Six Siege in my free time. Long story short, turns out playing Siege with brain-dead teammates was taking a toll on my mental health, so I took a break from gaming and started working out. That's when I got in touch with that old friend from 2019 who I used to play with. We caught up, and he told me he was getting married. We played a game of GTA Online together before going our separate ways. Grieving with nostalgia I looked at my game library. From GTA 5, Injustice 2, Fortnite, R6 Siege, Assassins Creed, and Ghost Recon Wildlands. Ghost Recon? I couldn't help but notice that Ghost Recon was the odd one out. I had no memory of playing it with him, so I downloaded it and gave it a try.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

REVIEW:
I don't know if it was my disdain for what Siege had become, but man did I fall in love with Wildlands. The story hooked me from the start, the UI was clean, and the game had such a deep and well-crafted weapon and cosmetic selection. In the past, I've played tactical games like Operation Flashpoint and Insurgency Sandstorm, but Wildlands felt real. it was modern, tactical, and clean. And the gameplay and story just further enhanced this


Gameplay:
The guns and gunplay for the most part are consistent. The guns sound and feel great, I only wish the game gave them more scopes. The way our character moves and interacts with the world is amazing as well. From having deep convos with the crew, hit firing when taking cover, removing/adding the suppresser, and shooting from their back while prone. I just love and appreciate the attention to detail that when into the gameplay. (There's a lot I'm leaving out but you get the gist)

Story:
You could definitely still feel that Ubisoft formula in the story but it somehow just works. I got fully immersed in the game's story, primarily because of Bowman, loved her character. The story combined with the world felt real and the way the music complimented everything was just amazing. 

But what really made it all a blast was the co-op. I played it with my brother, and we had a great time customizing our characters to suit each biome, grinding the skill tree, stealth infiltrations, role-playing, and just messing around and having fun. Unfortunately, all good things come to an end, and my brother eventually drifted away from the game. I still completed the game without him, but I couldn't bring myself to platinum it, because of how much of a grind it was. 

Overall, Ghost Recon was a lot of fun. I loved how it immersed me in its story and its world and how futuristic and tactical it was. It really made me feel like a mercenary, especially with no HUB. I'm honestly grateful for the attention to detail and care put into creating such a tactical and immersive game like Wildlands. I sometimes forget that Ghost Recon is a Ubisoft IP. And It's clear that Ubisoft can create amazing games when they take the time to do so.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
PS I bought Wildlands on PC for the performance and graphical improvement and have resumed playing it with my brother. It's still a blast, but only this time it's beautiful, smooth, and clean.

Several years ago, I played Splinter Cell Blacklist and appreciated the smooth character movement and precise controls. I hoped to see such game mechanics incorporated in other Ubisoft games.

Fortunately, Ghost Recon Wildlands was released soon after, featuring the same character movement and controls as Splinter Cell Blacklist. Ubisoft has since adopted these gameplay mechanics and controls in their modern 3rd person shooters, including The Division 1 & 2, which I found enjoyable as well. 

However, there's something remarkably captivating about Ghost Recon Wildlands that has me returning to it time and time again. The game offers a perfect balance between relaxation and exhilaration, making it an ideal companion for listening to podcasts. Although the story may not be the most enthralling, the gameplay itself is what truly transforms this game into a classic, engaging experience that never fails to entertain.

Also the biggest plus for me about this game is it runs really well under Linux (proton), which is my main setup for many years now.

If you like Open World/Sandbox Military-Type games this is for you. If you have never played a game like that then this game would be a great start. People complain about how this game can get repetitive, but if you're like me and spent hours and hours playing with plastic army men in the back yard this feels like a video game of that. 

It's a great game even until this day. Customization is AMAZING. Missions are fun! Characters are quirky and unique. It's most likely on sale due to its age. 

Just buy it and have fun with it.

Tom Clancy's Ghost ReconÂ® Wildlands is a great open-world and third-person shooter(TPS) game. In fact, it's a third-person version of the Far Cry series.

I'm not interested in military, but I've found this game really interesting. I think the game is good because the user-friendly and realistic elements of the game are in harmony. Personally, I liked the outfit and weapon customization.

The story wasn't quite interesting, but it was good. The twist in the second half was also very fresh.

The background and graphic description are really great. They've put all of Bolivia's natural environments into one map. Thanks to Ubisoft, I enjoyed my trip to Bolivia! I don't think Iâll go on a trip to Bolivia in the future.

Regarding the price of the game, when I first bought it, I thought the price was a little high even if I bought it at a discount, but after playing it, my regret disappeared. I thought the amount and quality of the game were very reasonable for the price.

It took more than 100 hours for me to play, but I think it depends on how others play. In fact, it was hard to play the Ubisoft-style open world game because of the great amount of its play time. I understood the concept of knocking down a huge enemy by cutting his arms and legs one by one, but I thought this was a little too much.

I'd like to recommend it to anyone who's interested in military.

Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands is an open world action tps that offers a fun gameplay and a surprisingly great story. 
Gameplay follows the usual Ubisoft formula. I usually hate it but what makes up for it is how the game feels to play. Playing stealthy and tactical is very rewarding. Getting in sync with your teammates and taking down enemies one by one then getting even better at strategising and executing your plans is super satisfying.
You can also go guns blazing in almost every mission though i wouldn't recommend it especially in harder missions.
Story seems very basic at the beginning but as you progress, it becomes better and sets itself apart from being a shallow mindless shooter.
There are of course some things that it does bad. The first one being the world design. It is massive and unfortunately very empty. Apart from key locations, the world consists of roads, foliage and vastness.
One big issue is the glitches and bugs. The game is riddled with them and you will encounter atleast 2 or 3 of them on each of your playthroughs. While some are are funny and harmless, a lot of them require you to restart the mission or die to get out of the bug.
Ubisoft launcher is another big issue. It just doesn't work most of the time and makes playing with friends a huge hassle.
The last one will be a mixed opinion which is the mission types. There isn't enough variety to keep it interesting. I enjoyed the game thoroughly but most will surely find it repetitive.
After all that negative there still are fun times waiting for you and your friends in Ghost Recon Wildlands.
Buy on sale if you like the ubisoft formula or more serious tactical shooters that you can play with friends.

The story is entertaining, and choosing what to do and where to go means you don't have to get stuck on one thing. My sincerest gratitude to Ubisoft for reaching out and trying to help resolve the issues I had (crashes). Fortunately for Ubisoft, the problem was on my end. Whenever I do something that is graphically intensive (even other games), my system would reboot. The simple fix: disable C-States in the BIOS. Well, well. It seems one day, you will play a modern Ubisoft games, with it's shooting a birdshot into a map-style layout and the seemingly slightly increasing stats that are very minute in the end for its "RPG" mechanics, or the simple sandbox gameplay that had too many things to held; which makes it basic for all of the things?

Either way, playing this game is the quintessential modern Ubisoft title. Ghost Recon! A game where, at the beginning is an essence of a classic Tom Clancy game (AI that is dumber than rocks but kills your entire team within seconds, a game style that revolves around making the perfect plan, and US troopers some backwaters somewhere within the Eastern Europe or Central Asia/Counter-Terror unit hunting some big name Terrorist), becomes something different at the end of the 2000s; more akin to a pseudo-sci-fi military shooter that is en vogue during those times.

Obviously, Wildlands is a departure from that formulae; since now its a standard Ubisoft sandbox but with third-person shooter mechanics. You have your choices of stealth (at higher levels, its mandatory) or loud (means you screwed yourself). The story itself is, uh.... something. It's obvious that aside from novels written by the late Tom Clancy himself, the games that are made with his name aren't exactly the pinnacle of storytelling. Ghost Recon Wildlands isn't an exception. Sure, it's fun hearing Diana Burnwood swear every other sentences, and hearing Male Nomad (whom, if I remember, is a Major and should be in his mid to late 30s) sounding like a teenager who learned every single swear word in the vocabulary and combining them to become cooler (Shitballs) is always funny for me.

The actual story itself, while simple, isn't the main drive of it. I don't think it is. The main drive is with the gameplay loop. Yes, it's as standard as apple pie with Ubisoft for putting Combat Outposts like its candy, but the fun part begins on how you tackle 'em. Nomad moves pretty well, any weapons you use is an auto-kill when hidden, and at higher levels; the game becomes your little plaything, especially when you have all the tools at hand (which you will need on some locations). Some weapons are build equally, others aren't. Shotguns are really bad in this game; since SMGs fill their role better and can hit targets above 50 meters. LMGs are always a treat to carry on loud missions, but they took forever to load, and using a M4A1/TAR-21/Famas with 50 round mag is better at that case.

There are many other complaints I would give. The car and bike physics felt like the cars have their tires sanded out, and the bike felt like driving with a very obese man on the back with how erratic it responded sometimes. But, my biggest complaint yet is with Unidad.

In the game, there's three factions: Kataris, Santa Blanca and Unidad. Kataris is the rebels you're working (and throwing their people into fire if you play 'em like me) with, Santa Blanca is the funny cartel people with the world's most annoying DJ and Mrs."IF YOU'RE NOT BOSSY, YOU GET WHAT YOU DESERVE" (Perico can you stop putting Nidia every 5 minutes you simp, I wish I actually shot her instead of dragging her into a chopper so Bowman has a Bosslady to Bosslady talk to her), and Unidad. Full stop.

If there's words I can describe Unidad is "swarms of rats". GTA V cops ain't got anything with these people. They have essentially a wanted mechanic, where if they spot you for more than 30 seconds, they will send a patrol at you. If that doesn't work: 2 patrols. No? APCs. "Oh, is that all", you may ask? If that's all, then it shouldn't be a problem! Sadly, the one thing that LSPD doesn't have with Unidad is the SHEER QUANTITY that they can throw at you. During one of the missions in Media Luna (the penultimate one), they send an entire platoon at me. Sure, you can just walk around 'em (and in fairness, that's what you should do), and you SHOULD have an Anti-Materiel Rifle at the ready for helicopters (if you don't, then you're screwed), but it does get really annoying at times when their patrols spotted you and you have to do the whole song and dance.
Don't get me started about the only-Unidad territories (Media Luna and Fior de Oro), those are an exercise of pain, patience and "AGAIN?" once you get spotted by a Unidad patrol and you didn't kill 'em fast enough. Admittedly, Fior de Oro has the best Assault Rifle in the game for me (M4A1 my beloved).

Sometimes, it's good that the AI is dumb as rocks. They only have two moods when spotting you: Laser-accurate shooting while in cover, or RUSH. Like, they will rush exactly at your location where you shoot 'em. Not even a 10 meters or two of deviation. Funnily enough, that's exactly how I take care of Unidad bases at that point. Since they're tankier than the average Sicario, the grunts are gonna rush in willy-nilly half of the time. So, you set up traps and mines for 'em. If not, and you already spotted 'em, just walk around and shoot 'em in the back. Sometimes, their cheating helps you since, like a Tactical Shooter AI, they're dumb as rocks.

While you may play the game without even leveling up or getting any weapons/attachment you want in the map is fine (P416, MP5 and M40A5 are solid weapons), the games does feel like it builds on the idea that you slowly build your Nomad to become a maniac with enough explosives to level an entire city, and carrying an entire arsenal that fits to their situation. Like, leveling up all your stuff to level 1 is a must for me, since you get all the tools you needed. When you reach to the point where you deal with Unidad, hopefully you already have a good LMG, Anti-Materiel Rifle and enough levels on Vehicular destruction. If not, then, uh, well, shit.

The customization in this game is uh... something. I kinda wish Nomad gets more than just four hairs, 12 faces and more gear that doesn't look off; but that's life.I guess that's on the sequel.

Either way, this game is worth playing.... on a discount. Don't buy it full price, you're an absolute buffoon if you do that.

Ghost Recon Wildlands is an open-world third-person shooter game developed by Ubisoft Paris and published by Ubisoft. Released in 2017, the game is set in a fictionalized version of Bolivia, where players take on the role of a special forces team tasked with taking down a drug cartel.

One of the standout features of Ghost Recon Wildlands is its massive open world, which offers players a vast and diverse environment to explore. The game's world is filled with different landscapes, including mountains, forests, deserts, and cities, each with its unique challenges and opportunities.

The game's tactical gameplay mechanics are also noteworthy, as they allow players to approach missions and combat situations in various ways. Players can choose to take a stealthy approach, using silenced weapons and carefully planning their actions, or opt for a more aggressive playstyle, using heavy firepower and vehicles to take down enemies.

Another aspect of the game that stands out is its multiplayer mode, which allows players to team up with friends or other players online to complete missions and take on the cartel together. The game's co-op mode adds to the game's overall replayability and provides players with a fun and challenging experience.

However, the game's story and characters are somewhat forgettable, and the game can feel repetitive at times, with many of the missions feeling similar to one another.

Overall, Ghost Recon Wildlands is an enjoyable open-world shooter game that offers a vast and diverse environment to explore and fun tactical gameplay mechanics. While the game's story and characters may not be its strongest point, the game's co-op mode and replayability make it worth checking out for fans of the genre.

One of the best open-world co-op shooters out there, and that's saying something.

In a sea of shameless copy-and-paste open world games there always has to be the one game that makes all the others look bad.

So this is an open-world (uh-huh,) co-op tactical light RPG shooter (mhm,) made by Ubisoft (Oh boy! THIS GAME IS SHIT!) That's actually worth the money.

-The Good-
The gameplay is feels amazing, the guns feel impactful and the roster is solid. Play this game on Advanced or Extreme and you will not regret it.

Ghost mode is meant for players who want more challenge and brings perma-death, no squad members and heightened difficulty for players seeking a challenge. In ghost mode, you start with a level 1 character with only the basic equipment*, and the reward you get for beating it is really special, I won't spoil it, but it sure is cool.

Co-op is where you take all the positives from this game and add your friends into the mix, making the gameplay experience more fun, and if you don't have people to play with, and don't like to play with randoms. The base game is still fun.

-The Bad-
You may have noticed the "*"'s I've been putting around, and that's because this a Ubisoft title so there is going to be some *'s attached to things.

* - In Ghost mode, you start with the basic starting equipment plus all the DLC and micro-transactions you bought.

The story is mid, you are taking down a drug cartel called "Santa Blanca" that has taken over the free country of Bolivia through violence and political dealings, who is shipping cocaine to the US and Canada, and who has also formed their own pseudo-religion and their leader is an extremely violent drug-lord that kills civilians and anyone who opposes him. 

But no rush, take your time.

The Ghosts have a very transparent personality, probably because they don't exist.

The main character "Nomad" is a blank piece of paper as a character, and every second word out of his mouth is "shitballs" so yeah have fun hearing that.

And that's all I can say about the Ghosts, I guess "Weaver" got Nomad into a car accident one time so that's why he lost his driving privileges, however this is never elaborated on.

All the cartel members are, actually I don't remember I'll have to get back to you on this.

-Conclusion-
Ghost Recon Wildlands is a really fun open-world light RPG tactical shooter that stands out, as it is actually good, the gameplay is fun on the harder difficulties and it offers the insanely fun ghost mode for those looking for a challenge, and the game is even more fun with your friends but is great on its own

TL;DR. If you get this 80% off, and have friends to play it with, it's worth it. At full price it is not. Game has bugs, micro transactions, and loot boxes. And an uninspiring and at times incoherent story. In general, I enjoyed this game. However, that comes with a few caveats. Firstly, I got this when it was 80% off. There is no chance that this game would be even nearly worth it at its full price of $75 AUD.For the base price of $75, youâre not even given everything, in true Ubisoft fashion there is still loot boxes and micro transactions. Also requires the Ubisoft game launcher (which can be quite annoying).Also, this is one of those games that requires mates to play with. In single player the AI companions are annoying at best and a big hinderance at worst. Fortunately, you can disable them in the settings menu, but be prepared for a difficulty spike over playing co-op.The story is also uninspiring and bland. If you want something story rich, maybe look somewhere else. On top of that some of the character's voice acting in a few places could use some, [i]work[/i]. Though for most characters the voice acting is pretty good. But the excessive use of 'tango' does annoy me. I get the use of it, being an elite recon team, but hearing it a hundred times in a single encounter, it's a bit over done.On top of micro-transactions and loot box mechanics, even after the age of this game, bugs are still everywhere. Gotta love falling through the map after exiting a helicopter and dying, getting spotted through vehicles, or failing a stealth mission because the rebels decided to start a faction warfare. But probably the most annoying is how inconsistent inviting people to your lobby is. My mate and I typically spend 15 min restarting the game trying to get the invite to work. A constant loop of 'in menus (unavailable)', and other features that are just broken. E.g., the prompt asking if you want to rejoin a game after crashing or quitting is broken, and always results in a message saying Ubisoft services are down, along with a couple other game joining features.Also falls into the common [i]go stealth or go loud[/i] games where if your going stealth, and the enemy is alerted (e.g., finds dead body), they can magically know where you are. Nothing is more annoying than being up on a massive hill sniping, someone finds a dead body, and then a few min later a patrol is just magically behind you. While this isn't game breaking, it is very annoying and is something you should be aware of.Also, toward the end of the game upgrading can get a bit grindy and tedious, constantly running around trying to get enough resources to unlock the next tier of a single skill. And of course you can also use micro transactions to skip the grind, thanks Ubisoft.Though overall I did enjoy the game, I still don't recommend it at it's full listed price.

This is a really fun to play large open world shooter, with nice graphics and cool weapons. On the up side, the fast travel and  the support facility to request vehicles makes traversing the world a lot easier. However, on the down side, the aeroplane controls are horrific, the quests feel repetitive in nature , your AI teammates are fairly useless outside of sync'd shots, and finally ultimately nothing you do has any consequence. You can kill anyone, civilian or rebel or bad guy and they eventually respawn. Don't get me starting on jumping. You cannot jump. There is this annoying cross mechanic where you can vault over things but the lack of jumping makes some movement and interaction with the world quite tedious. The stealth aspects are sufficiently arcade and limited that eventually you get spotted and most larger area more end game fights / infiltrations end up in a gun fight with you against insurmountable waves of vehicles and helicopters where all you can do is shoot until you run out of ammo and then run away.In the end it starts to feel like quite a chore and new weapons are very rare without real world money purchases. Oh and even without considering multiplayer, ubisoft connect is awful and regularly battles to connect. Eventually, the frustration was overwhelming and I just stopped playing. Unfortunate and disappointing.

Such a classic. This game is probably my favorite tactical shooter of all time. There's just a perfect balance of simulation and arcade mechanics that make this game-play smooth and fun. Graphics were beautiful at the time of release, and for the most part, they still are today. However, in 2023, they tend to be a little more 'good from far, but far from good'. Regardless, this game is just an all-around treat to play. And once I begin a campaign, its hard to put this game down until completion. Really hope they make a sequel to this game before they pour more wasted efforts into breakpoint, which i found to be a step backwards from Wildlands. This is also one of my favorite games to play online co-op w friends: flying a chopper over an enemy base, one guy jumps out and sky dives to a vantage point on top a hill overlooking the base. The other player and I land the helicopter nearby and slowly and quietly advance into the enemy base. The sniper tactically picking off enemies before they spot us... I could go on and on, but to sum it all up: its pure fun and entertainment.

You continue on. The game feels much like other Ubisoft games (such as FarCry), it has the same map, the same inventory system, the same ubiquitous online tie-in to the UbiSoft Store and Club. If it weren't Ubisoft, it would simply be a preposterous shooter, which would probably be ok...

Like a gob of sh* thrown on the Mona Lisa, this game's beautiful open world is utterly ruined by escalating difficulty and painfully long reloading times (the game, not your guns in game). I've played ghost recon and splinter cell from the beginning. I was excited to play a stealth action game after the seeming death of the genre (although the original Ghost Recon was more strategy than stealth). This game however, is just not fun. It's amazing aesthetics and customization only raise your expectations to be utterly crushed.

I've maxed out my stealth abilities and tooled out my silent weapons and there's seemingly no difference in detection times or ability to stay stealthy. I completed the missions to get the stealth optic camouflage and it doesn't make a difference to anything. Enemies will still see you and alert the entire base in a second. I even turned down the difficulty to 'Arcade', the game's easiest setting, and there's no discernible difference.

For the enemy AI being so incredible at homing in on you and shooting you with extreme precision, your squad-mates' AI is hot garbage. They are constantly losing marks and getting caught by the enemy, often times costing you missions... which is made worse by the game's reload times. I can get up and go make some coffee while the game reloads. Even with my rig above recommended specs and Ethernet hard-lined in. Now I understand why old-school stealth games just had the enemies resume their regular patrol routes so fast.     
-That was a meme but here it would be welcome so we wouldn't have to reload the whole damn game.

You get some cool gadgets that just end up being worthless junk. You can't use mines because civilians run over them constantly. The fact that the quietest weapons still suck makes every other weapon utterly useless. Also, once enemies are alerted they become bullet sponges. I've shot a dude in the face, point blank with my M14, 3 or more times before they go down. Same with the Vector .45 SMG. Kinda weird how an alerted armored enemy is almost as tough as a vehicle, but you can one-shot them when firing from stealth.

Overall, this game is so close to being a beautiful masterpiece that could breath life into the now extinct stealth action genre, it just pisses you off they could fumble it so bad. It should be re-named "Souls-Recon: A Fromsoftware wannabe."

Still the benchmark in open world shooters, especially in covert/black ops settings.
If the gunplay (bullet drop) in a tactical shooter is the weakest feature, it tells you how the game shines in other areas.

Missions or just base clearing never gets boring since you can apply different techniques from stealthy to heavy shoot out.
The Open World is extremely immersive. The world itself is not felt repetitive like Breakpoint, e.g.
During the Story you get also missions which do not incude shooting, stealing, planting evidence, getting compromat for black-mailing.
The banter of AI-squad members reminds you of Baldur's Gate.

RPG mechanics do not get get too intrusive and luckily it stays away from turning enemies into bullet sponges. One shot or a two or three bullet burst well placed usually do the trick.

Atmosphere and fun gameplay rule. As a tactical shooter it hits the sweet spot between MilSim and more arcade style or shooters or loot shooters.

I recommend to first play the single player campaign alone, and then replay in coop with friends.

Extremely fun and engaging game with some of the best graphics I've seen in a third-person open-world shooter. The nation of Bolivia presented within this game feels authentic and lived-in with multiple biomes ranging from dense jungles to mountainous ranges and even snow-capped mountains, all woven together seamlessly. 

There is roughly 80 hours of content in the base game should you take your time to complete everything the game has to offer. There are multiple side objectives to complete and collectables to find, with a large number of which providing accurate historical and cultural information regarding Bolivia's real-world customs and beliefs. The weapons on offer are all extremely satisfying to use, with attachments and new firearms requiring one to find them throughout the world. There are also rebel-assistive perks that can expand your options for tackling any situation, such as the command to request rebel infantry support, vehicle drop-offs and even mortar fire on a designated location. The process of scouting out enemy positions is conducted through the use of your personal drone, which can also be upgraded to become a portable EMP, a noise emitter or even a remote control bomb.

Highly recommend to anyone who enjoys open-world games that encourage stealthy approaches to combat, yet are not punished for taking gunfights head-on.

Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands is a well-crafted tactical shooter that offers a vast and immersive open-world environment for players to explore. The game's storyline is interesting, with players tasked with taking down a powerful drug cartel operating in Bolivia. The game's graphics are also impressive, with stunning visuals that add to the realism and atmosphere of the game.

One of the highlights of the game is its cooperative multiplayer mode, which allows players to team up with up to three other players to complete missions and take down the cartel. This mode adds a lot of replayability to the game and makes it a great option for those who enjoy team-based gameplay.

The game's weapon customization and upgrade system is also well-designed, allowing players to tailor their weapons to their playstyle and become more effective in combat. The game's vehicles and gadgets also add to the variety of gameplay options available to players.

However, the game's open-world environment can feel overwhelming at times, with a large number of side missions and activities to complete. The game's AI can also be frustrating at times, with enemies sometimes behaving in unrealistic ways or being too easy to take down.

Overall, Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands is a great game for fans of tactical shooters and open-world gameplay. While it has some minor flaws, its cooperative multiplayer mode, customization options, and immersive world make it a worthwhile game to check out.

This is possibly my favorite game of all time, and anyone looking for an immersive, tactical, squad-based shooter should look no further.

First of all, the game is beautiful to look at, even six years after release. You'll explore Bolivia's salt flats, dominating snow-capped mountains, swamps, lakes, and fields of the infamous coca plant as you take down outposts, destroy convoys for precious loot, and pursue missions that have a decent variety that keep you intrigued. The open world is dynamic, though perhaps feels a bit empty, but if you stick to your modus operandi of striking unwitting opponents and disappearing before anyone was the wiser, it will suffice.

There are a variety of ways to handle each enemy encounter, but I find stealth to be this game's strong suit. Much has been made of the inability to move/hide bodies (a detail fixed in the sequel, Ghost Recon Breakpoint), but I love the increased difficulty this can add to the game's stealth encounters. What really unlocks this game's full potential is the "Ghost Mode," or permadeath mode you can play with your friends. It amps up the tension, and is absolutely a serious challenge for gamers.

This game's strongest weaknesses lie with the AI, both your AI teammates and the enemies can be pretty bone-headed at times, and their behavior can be predictable. But, due to reinforcements coming if you alert the base, every encounter is difficult enough to take seriously. The story is also laughably jingoistic and ridiculous; don't come to Wildlands for a page-turner. But that's okay when you can get immersed in the world on your own, and get lost in the wildlands of Bolivia.

I love this game, I've probably sunk more hours into it than any game I've ever played, and I hope many more people can experience what it has to offer.

This game is a masterpiece. If you like tactical shooters and open world, there is no better game (even its sequel Breakpoint is not as good).

The gameplay is fantastic: A huge campaign with parallel missions (in fact this is a tree you can solve in any order), taking place in a gigantic, credible open world. Everything is possible from your gun to flying helicopter. You can even play the campaign in coop, up to 4 players!

The graphics are superb. Its sequel Breakpoint is a notch higher, however, the feeling of being in a foreign country with all its colors and culture is incredibly well rendered in Wildlands.

The audio is great as well: from all tactical stuff to inhabitants dancing on the main square, celebrating stuff in towns. You really feel you are here.

Indeed, unlike 99% of other open world games, this one is really immersive: It feels like you are in a real country with real civilian people doing their stuff. While the bad guys are just a small part of the population. 

You can customize the difficulty to your liking. I played without any help (no HUD), just two weapons, ârealisticâ clothes, and all, and it was fun to drive down the roads, listening to the radio, reading the map, to know where to turn to reach the next town where my target was.

This game is half arcade, half simulation. Weapons are from real life. However, they are (un)balanced for gameplay. No weapon is really better than another, and they do not necessarily match their real-life characteristics. Now, that said, they are great fun. You can customize them to death, same for your outfit and loadout.

It is great to play coop, one player infiltrating with his gun and knife, while a sniper is covering him from afar. Even in solo, the bots, while not great, are fine. They canât break your missions, and do whatever you ask of them.

To date, this is the best open world tactical shooter I have played in a long time. While Breakpoint is a notch higher technically. Wildland campaign, characters and overall gameplay is better. I like how the world is full or real civilian people, not just bad guys, and stupid dronesâ¦

Buy it, even at full price, this game is a gem.

A pretty good game. Stealth is handled pretty well, shooting feels good, and the atmosphere of the world and story is done very well.

Some of the things it could improve on are the movement mechanics and mission design. The movement is very context-dependent like in other Ubisoft games. i.e. you can't jump unless there is an obstacle that you can press A on to activate the jumping animation. This works fine for the most part, but there are some obstacles in the open world which appear easily passable but that you cannot press A on. This can be really disappointing when it ruins your carefully planned stealth approach. As for mission design, there are some missions where enemies just spawn out of nowhere. This just seems like a lazy way to create a sense of urgency, and clashes with the stealthy and precise tone of the game. The convoy missions are another irritation. If I can shoot out the driver, it is very satisfying, but usually I can't do that. These missions often devolve into a goofy-ass car chase, which, again, clashes with the tone of the game. My final complaint is that the guns don't feel very unique from each other. There are several assault rifles that feel the same, and the same goes for smgs and snipers. I didn't find much use for shotguns. I guess the variety is just there for style/customization, which is fine I guess.

Ghost Recon Wildlands is an outstanding masterpiece of the gaming world that is sure to capture the imagination of players across the globe. The game is an action-packed third-person shooter that offers players a thrilling experience in the vast and breathtaking landscapes of Bolivia.

As soon as players embark on their mission, they will be instantly awed by the sheer size and beauty of the open-world map. The game's attention to detail is truly remarkable, and every nook and cranny of the game's environment is meticulously designed, from the bustling cities to the dense jungles and everything in between.

The game's combat mechanics are smooth and intuitive, and the game rewards players for their strategic prowess and tactical planning. Whether players choose to go in guns blazing or take a more stealthy approach, they will find that the game provides ample opportunities for both.

One of the most impressive features of Ghost Recon Wildlands is the game's AI. The enemies are intelligent and will react to the player's actions, making for an unpredictable and exciting gameplay experience. The game also allows players to team up with up to three other players in co-op mode, making for even more intense and thrilling gameplay.

The game's story is engaging and immersive, with a host of interesting characters and plot twists that will keep players hooked from start to finish. The voice acting is top-notch, and the game's soundtrack perfectly complements the action-packed gameplay.

In conclusion, Ghost Recon Wildlands is an outstanding game that offers players an incredible and immersive gaming experience. Its attention to detail, smooth combat mechanics, and engaging story make it a must-play for any fan of the action and shooter genres. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or a newcomer to the world of gaming, Ghost Recon Wildlands is sure to impress and entertain you.

TOM CLANCY'S GHOST RECON: WILDLANDS - '' Some Are Soldiers, We Are Ghosts'' - 

1 ABOUT) -
Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands is a tenth installment of tactical shooter video game by Ubisoft and first game in the Ghost Recon series with open world. The game offer third-person perspective and optional first-person view for gun aiming. Unlike GR Wildlands predecessors, the game consist from main and side missions. After completing missions, players can reach the locations where the mission starts or where they want to go. The game offer you Classic campaigne mode, Guerrilla mode, Ghost mode and Ghost War mode with 2 DLC's, Narco Road and Fallen Ghosts (exclusive Predator event is no more supported).
2 GAMEPLAY ) -
Players can parachute from helicopters and planes, walk overland, driving vehicles towards their objectives. Also they can grab enemies at close range or use them like a human shield, gain experience points, also available is customization characters including their AI teammates, and more. Every weapon and gear can be upgraded. Wounded characters will be healed automatically and your dying teammates can be revived. The game can be played solo with AI teammates, which player can give orders or they can be disabled via  the game settings. GR Wildlands is playable like PVP and PVE, offer you many activities. In CO-OP mode players can be joined by other three players, to complete missions and explore the game's world together. 
3 PLOT ) -
Ghost Recon Wildlands take a place in Bolivia in 2019. The Sounth American country has become unstable after that brutal and religious drug cartel boss ''El Sueno'' and his ''Santa Blanca'' gains a control over several location in the Bolivia. Meanwhile the Bolivian government established ''La Unidad'' special semi-military forces for fighting with Santa Blanca's thugs. In the same time DEA agent Ricardo Sandoval has disappeared probably after his attempt to infiltrate El Sueno's cartel. Ghost Recon team is here deployed as a part of  special ''Operation Kingslayer'' joined by CIA, DEA, JSOC and Pac Katari's rebels. 
Aftermath of Operation Kingslayer the Bolivian government trying remnants of tactical police unit Unidad reformed into the ''Los Extranjeros'' which is corrupted and now take control of over cocaine's production.
Somewhere in Bolivia CIA trying reveal identity and find a location of Santa Blanca's head of smuggling network ''El Invisible'', they sent Ghost in undercover to find a clues of El Invisible's identity and stop activities of Santa Blanca's remnants. 
4 REVIEW) - 
For me is Ghost Recon: Wildlands the best part of franchise, which offer refined story, an action, a thrill, interesting locations and landscapes, battlefields, multiple weapons and gears. It's ultimate adventure with promise of never ending pleasure from playing. I think that Ghost Recon: Wildlands is really one of many Ubisoft's masterpieces and that's reason why I give it full 10/10 points. It's really a very good work.

Wildlands is a game you'll want to try out. It is a fun open world tactical shooter. The team that worked on this game did so for 5 long years and you can tell. The world they crafted is extremely immersive and feels very authentic. It's the same feeling I get when I play the Witcher 3 and walk through Novigrad...you can tell the devs put a lot of love and care into making it. Every house has little assets here and there from candles to plates to just random clutter. That takes a long time considering how big the world is. Same with Bolivia. Every Sicario house you walk in looks authentic and believable. Every area you explore makes you feel like you are there. The game mechanics are familiar if you've played other tittles from Ubisoft, but there is a lot here you can play with. From having an up-gradable drone that you can use to pre-spot bases and hideouts and using it to distract enemies. You have a plethora of firepower from handguns to SMGs and LMGs, assault rifles and sniper rifles. Grenades, proximity mines, C4, regular mines, flashbangs and on top of all that, rebels that you can call in for back up, diversion or other tactics. This allows you to approach every fight in the manner that fits your play style. If you get the DLCs you can also get a knife so you can do stealthy take downs. The game is huge, the world is beautiful and very well crafted and the story is decent too. I think Ubisoft should stick to this formula, cause that Frontline battle royale idea they had is absolute garbage and will without a doubt ruin this franchise. I recommend this game, especially now that they are back on Steam and you'll most likely be able to pick it up on sale

The further you get into this exploitative,  lootbox-based product, the worse the writing gets. It gets worst of all with the absolutely awful crossover missions which are quite literally intended to promote ANOTHER lootbox-infested Ubisoft product, that being [i]Rainbow 6 Siege.[/i]

[h1]Lootboxes[/h1]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2924173593

This game has a monetization system which is WORSE than the [i]Far Cry[/i] games in that it locks popular weapons like the AK-74 ENTIRELY behind lootboxes. If you want an AK-74, you can buy lootboxes. That's it. There isn't even an option to unlock these lootboxes by grinding in the game nor is there an option to purchase the lootbox guns directly. This is literally WORSE than even [i]Call of Duty[/i] as of the last time I played that product.

[h1]Bad writing[/h1]

The writing for this game starts out bad... and then it falls off a cliff. The ending of the story is basically the worst part of the whole game with plot twists which quite literally make no sense and come out of nowhere. It also suffers from a bad case of "F*** you for caring" syndrome AKA "Druckman's disease" in that it goes out of its way to make you feel let down if you actually made the mistake of caring about the characters.

Oh... but then it gets much worse with the crossover missions intended to hype the "characters" in [i]Rainbow Six Seige[/i]... a game that literally doesn't have any characters because it is live service trash with NO story. 

[h1]More hateful, edgelord trash that wasn't even play-tested properly[/h1]

Not only is the trash-tier writing in the crossover abominations gratingly bad (being the product of the same minds that created an unlikable, Mary Sue war-criminal in [i]Far Cry 6[/i] and then tried to convince us that is was "progressive" because that particular self-absorbed psychopath was ALSO trans) the several missions this adds aren't even play-tested. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2924161803

One of them, about a Mary Sue torture-lady who literally wears a skull mask (this series is written by edgelord children) is riddled with bugs that literally create fail states. (I encountered two different fail-state creating bugs in a single mission in a single-play session that consisted of retrying the SAME mission repeatedly to try to get it to work.) 

Another mission (intended to promote another Ubisoft franchise) has a stealth system so badly implemented that you will literally fail it and thus get stuck in a loading screen when you AREN'T EVEN PLAYING IT! The trash programming creates a fail state that kicks you back to the loading screen the any guard in a HUGE area goes into combat EVEN WHEN YOU AREN'T DOING THAT MISSION and RANDOM NPCs can trigger combat in that area if you are anywhere near it even when you aren't detected yourself.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2926640301

Worse still, as you can see above, this mission even makes you wait until a certain time of day to start. You can't just skip it. You have to wait until the right time... like in Shenmue. 

Even if this worked on a technical level, the hateful, nihilistic and frankly childish writing for a series of side-missions which are basically just designed to promote other Ubisoft products would make them a dubious addition to the game. With the bugs and bad game design though, it actually makes the game WORSE if you buy this DLC because now you can fail missions in the regular game for no reason just because you got close enough to the DLC for the random NPCs to kick you back to the loading screen.

This garbage shouldn't exist. In fact, it was experiencing the horror of these crossover missions that finally motivated me to get around to reviewing this despicable product. 

[h1]This makes me sad...[/h1]

I honestly would have liked to recommend this game because with the exception of the rushed stealth system and the buggy crossover missions, this DOES have the bones of an unmatched military shooter. However, those are buried beneath microtransactions and writing so bad that it is almost "iconic'. 

I can't recommend this game because between the microtransactions, the garbage writing, and the broken stealth system, this game made me very angry even BEFORE I got to the utter trash that is the crossover missions.

I had fun in this game. There were definitely some great moments, and  the co-op is where most of the enjoyment was for me. But, objectively, this game is one of the least polished, most poorly made, and disappointing games I have ever played from a major studio. I am legitimately surprised that Ubisoft let the game go at this state. Well, maybe I shouldn't be.

Ignoring all the intentional decisions, one major issue with the game that you will likely notice is the impressive amount of bugs. I encountered some "minor" issues such as:

- Clipping textures
- Complete dialogue malfunctions (Voice lines playing from wrong character, wrong voice lines playing, same voice line playing multiple times, etc.)
- Needlessly far/oddly inconvenient vehicle spawns 
- Occasional stutters

And more. I can personally overlook bugs like those. What I can't overlook, though, is the absolutely mind-boggling amount of game-breaking bugs, glitches, and issues I encountered in my playthrough. These included:

- Missions disappearing from map
- Enemies detecting and shooting you through solid cover
- AI teammates/NPCs being stupid, (i.e. walking right in front of you while you are shooting)
- Vehicles exploding spontaneously, with no external damage

And many, many more. Unfortunately, my issues with the game don't end with the bugs (that are still not fixed, over 5 years after release). There are also some issues that come from conscious choices made during development, that reflect the lack of effort from Ubisoft to actually put real effort into this game.

The performance that I had playing this game on PC was laughable. Even on the lowest settings, I could only achieve 80-90 FPS maximum (In very rare cases) and in certain environments I would see frame drops down to the low 20s, with the stutters that I mentioned earlier. I had averages from 40-60 FPS, which is very low for my hardware when compared to other, similar games. Although I expected this game to be demanding, I see no reason that this runs so poorly even when compared to other Ubisoft games of similar (or better) visual quality.

The story of GRW I felt was very uninspired and generic. The characters can be forgettable, and the voice acting is HORRIBLE. Seriously. The main character sounds like a 17 year old doing his best "generic military guy" impression, complete with cringe-worthy humor. (If I hear the word "s***balls" come out of his mouth one more time, I think I might go insane)

The gameplay, while fun at times, really suffers from a lack of creativity. While you do technically have "hundreds of hours" of content in the game, it really only consists of hundreds of repetitive, mundane, and generic missions. Some of my least favorite were the stealth missions. You would think that the company responsible for Splinter Cell would have good ones, right? Well, I wholeheartedly believe that this game was just not made for stealth gameplay. Annoying enemy placement, bad AI, and no unique stealth mechanics make most of the stealth sections in this game either barely a challenge, or near impossible when combined with additional requirements like "Do not kill any enemies".

I also have to mention the multiplayer issues I faced. Due to Ubisoft's magnificent networking prowess, you will probably have better luck trying to scam Bill Gates with a phishing email than you will trying to get into a co-op session with your friend(s). We were CONSTANTLY plagued with random network errors every time we booted up the game, and short, 15 minute sessions quickly became 10 minutes of restarting the game and pressing random options, hoping the game would let us join each other. And that is assuming that Ubisoft servers are currently online, which itself is not guaranteed.

I can't end the review without at least a couple positives though. Ubisoft did an amazing job bringing such a large map to life, while still giving each section variety. I also do think that the "mexico cartel leader takedown" game format has a lot of potential and if adapted to be a more linear experience, (Maybe inspiration from Sicario?) could work very well.

Overall, even though I did have fun playing this game, I have to realize that it was probably only because I played the co-op campaign with a close friend. I have to think that if I had purchased this game for solo play only, I would have refunded it very quickly. For this reason, I can't recommend it to most people, especially at the insane normal pricing of $49.99. Get it on sale if you want some co-op fun with friends.

If you're looking for a game to reel you in and get deeply immersed, only to then pound you with headaches constantly, [i]Tom Clancy's Ghost ReconÂ® Wildlands[/i] will suit you.

The campaign has about 50 hours of solid gameplay, but is stretched out to double that. By the end it feels like a chore just to see the real ending, that's near identical to the one you're offered halfway through. 

The crossover content is neat but that's about the freshest parts after the 50 hour mark. It's just so repetitive! I recommend waiting till about 1/3 of the way through to play either of the [spoiler]Splinter Cell or Rainbow Six[/spoiler] missions, and play the other one 2/3rds through just to break up the monotony.

There was also too many issues for running on a high-end system. Task switching out and back caused major stutters until restarting, controller constantly dropping in and out, and crashing to desktop unless XMP was disabled. ([i]It was only in this game, my system runs everything else fineâ½[/i])

If you're comfortable with not finishing games, then its worth a go, otherwise it just loses the wind from its sails partway through and becomes a lacklustre experience with a disappointing conclusion. 

The most satisfactory part of completion is not having to hear "Sure are a lot of lights and switches up here!", âI got a Sicario carrying sub machine guns. Over by that stack of tires.â and "and baby makes three." twenty God damn times an hour!

I picked this up way before when couple of my mates recommended me that I should play coop with them. But I never really got around until a little over a week ago and now i'm at 75 hr mark. My background is that i played none of the ghost recon before and first ever ubisoft game that i played was ACO so i'm not one of those old kids who knew ubisoft at their heights.

I quite liked ACO for all its flaws so quite naturally, I quite like this game. Its still this usual ubisoft open-world bullshit where there's a lot of markers, wall banging mechanics and shitty dialogue, Just like AC:Odyssey you have your little drone and mark targets, go in and kill everybody.. rinse and repeat, again, not very deep. Run of the mill Ubisoft game. You stab people in their buttholes in AC:Odyssey; Here you drop them with guns. 

The part that sold me in both of those game is the world that we traverse in. Just like Greece, Bolivia in this game is beautiful from lush jungles to dessert and it brings a lot of role playing and immersion to the table. Basically the virtual tourism as the world, the terrain is designed very realistically and quite fun to explore. Because of this rich atmosphere, the role playing aspect is quite fun too. Not that one has to but if you wish to run like those green berets from "clear and present danger" movie, you can. If you want to run like Alejandro from Sicario movie? you can. 

Not so good parts of the games are present with every ubisoft games. Its bloated, too long at times so you might get bored if you're not very thrilled to walk and take in the scenery. Ubisoft games are basically the McDonalds of gaming. 

So, are you bored with games and dunno what to play? this game is the perfect side chick for you.

[UPDATE - HONEST] I have to say this game is getting terribly boring not because they added Future Soldier (Optimal camo is useless, it let you know how cool you are), Fisher, or Rainbow Six missions but its the Ghost Mode that made me grind till I decided to quit. It completely bounce against the purpose of why Wildlands is made for. Playing that on a full online squad with Extreme mode on is a pain in the a$$ and its super annoying. If you ever died from a glitch, stupid death from your teammates or ANY SITUATION, your character is deleted. Another thing that I hate about this is CRASHES 100% if you return to the menu from Ghost Mode, how do you even manage to do that??? For me, there is nothing challenging in the Ghost Mode, it just shows how retarted your are playing the campaign again, get serious like you're playing Arma 3, and hope you die for good. 

The store is a microtransaction with non-sense guns on sale that you can actually grind more or get chances to open Prestige or Spec Ops crates which completely useless. If you want to quick skip over your components or your guns you can always buy it when you enter Ghost Mode so you dont have to look for them again in the game.

What I can say from this is that if you want to have a family-friendly fun experience with your team, go for normal mode. Its better to do solo in Ghost Mode to grind for those exoskeleton things because the AI can teleport to heal you at any moment than your teammates (remember CoD: Advanced Warfare?) that doesn't look appeal at all because thats the only purpose that you must do. I adore this game, it sits in a special place between Far Cry 3 and Metal Gear Solid V, why do I adore it so much? Multiplayer, the shenanigans I've gotten up to with buddies has far outweighed the cons. Difficulty, this game is very easy unless you choose to add certain limitations to your own gameplay, I highly recommend playing with minimal HUD, on advanced difficulty to truly enjoy the scenery and atmosphere, being able to watch exactly where enemies are is simply far too easy, guiding my friend through a base using utility drone skills is truly satisfying.

Pros-
Multiplayer - seamless, drop-in and out, really a necessity in my opinion.
Customisation - Down to the trigger mechanism of your weapon, you can really refine your tools to match your playstyle.
Breadth - The game is massive, repetitive at times but the size and variance lies in the missions and regions.
Multiple difficulties - As you progress you will find it easier to enter and complete objectives in the higher difficulty regions, this is where the fun truly lives, it is challenging and rewarding.

Cons-
Ally AI - Garbage, not fun, more of a safety net than a tool at your disposal.
Repetition - The missions outside of the main objectives are copy pasted to different areas, they are brief however and doesn't detract too far into mediocrity.
Enemy AI - Stealth is a bit easy, but frankly, you can make this harder with difficulty settings.
Vehicle Physics - Batshit retarded, hilarious but awful, I didn't personally mind but don't expect much at all.

OVERALL -
Play this with friends, set your difficulty higher, minimize the HUD, don't take it too seriously and you will have a truly unique and immersive experience the way that I believe the game was meant to be played, this is Tom Clancy's Far Cry.

Wildlands looks beautiful with its stunning graphics and its huge open world. It provides the impression to be deep and realistic, when in fact it's rather shallow in both gameplay and lore. 

You are an elite soldier in a foreign country and your job is to either kill the bad guys or steal their stuff because... well, they are the bad guys who must be stopped. No need for diplomacy, no need for asking any more questions. 

Tactical combat play is solid, some nice features here like the drone exploration. Combine that with generic story, generic quests, generic characters, generic dialogues and a highly detailed world, which would have been a great opportunity to learn something about not so far Bolivia, its people, its culture on the fly, but no. Detailed environments are just non-interactive scenery for the "ultimate military shooter experience". And shooting, sneaking, driving, flying you can, "total freedom" they say and even physical limits are not unviolable. 

In sum though, at least for me, that's not enough to make for a remarkable game. Wildlands is not really bad when played with friends. But it's not good either. It's missing teeth, cleverness, empathy and charisma and while my mates are liking it, personally I've expected more.

Wildlands is a fun game; however, it is very buggy with badly designed interface. It spawns vehicles that immediately blow up because the spawn point happens to randomly coincide with some other vehicle or obstacle. It uses save check points, which is the worst trop in video game design. In this particular game it will lock you in a fail loop if you happen to make a mistake during the mission. The game will fail you, and spawn you right back in to the point of failure, fail the mission, reload, spawn in to the point of failure, fail the mission and so on in a loop. The only way to get out of it is to completely restart the game. If you happen to not complete a mission (because you had to quit the game and leave the computer, or you fail the mission at some unlucky way) the game will keep spawning enemy cars on top of you immediately as you load and instantly kill you, or when you are locked in a preset dialogue animation and can't fight back. Reload, span cars and so on in the loop. This game requires you to be connected to Ubisoft servers that are no longer maintained and it gives you a connect error for about 80% of connection attempts. The support as usual blames that on firewalls or routers, but this happens even if you turn of all firewalls and put your computer in to DMZ. (Do not do that). This game will not be patched. All development is stopped on it. There are no fixes and never will be. So even though it is a lot of fun when it is working it is more trouble than fun when it does not. And most of the time this game is a load of frustration. Avoid this title and spend your money on something else.

Bought the game for 9 euros on sale and thought it was a good deal, however I was going to be proven how wrong I was.

Even after soon 5 years from it's release date on March 7 2017 it still has issues with the connectivity and game crashes.

I was booted from online session and could not go online until I found a reddit post mentioning that you first had to access the ingame store before you could go online.

On my second attempt during the 2 hour deadline steam has to be eligible for refund for any purchased game, my game crash right smack middle of the COOP mission and made us restart the entire session for us to continue from scratch.


For my third and final attempt to give the game a chance me and my friend tried a open world mission of stopping a medical convoy, and oh boy here you could really see the issues that still plauges this game to this day. Issue number 1: The objective was not showing at the same location when we tried to shoot it. My friend has the objective behind us according to the map and could not see the escort at all, while for me I could see the escort but not damage it.

Issue number 2: Glitching, when we found out that the open world mission was scuffed, we stole a car and immediately two AI vechiles with miniguns and 4 bots in each spawned, these we could bearly kill and that was due to I could not use any guns. I was still stuck in the car animation when leaving the car which prohibited any use of weapons and could only be fixed if both parties died and reset the checkpoint.

Issue number 3: Bad performance even on newer rigs.
Even with latest Intel I5 processor and 3070 GTX card the game run like garbage and both me and my friend and to downscale the graphics to high to be some what playable.

Conclusion: Not recommended even if it's on sale! There is no excuse for such a big game developer to not have fixed these type of issues even after soon five years from release.
